I might come back every thanksgiving. So if you decide to do that also, you won't be the only one. The line was extremely long and the bar was full. However, the line went by faster than I thought. I'll come back. I'm always coming back.  I really have to try the daily specials. I'm always hearing great stuff about it.

azenhsJVTPxlFp8P1GfEeQ.review_text: Comfort food...drunk food...just plain hungry? Tommy's Joynt is great food.  I remember seeing this place when I stayed in a motel and swore that I must head in when I lived in the city. Lo and behold I neglected this place for a year or two except for the past few months, and I'm sad it took me this long to finally eat here.  You can grab a dinner plate with carvings of your particular meat, which is normally a generous portion. The carvers are good about trying to cut away the fatty portions. The meats are normally lean and melts in your mouth.  I've tried the Ox-tail and it was very sweet, so be warn before you order. I liked it, but my friends were not as satisfied.  They have a huge variety of beer from around the world and different versions of the typical Irish coffee.   Service is amazing and quick. Remember to use the tray just for transporting your food, because a server will swing by and grab those trays immediately.  Décor feels like a dining hall or sports bar with its all wooden interior and a mix between booths and picnic style tables and chairs.  I will definitely be back to try their other daily specials.

iOjwFYpHWo7P0rqmIfLm9g.review_text: You might have seen Tommy's- either driving down Van Ness or on Dinners Drive ins and Dives....but it is a brightly painted building with the sign that proudly exclaims "we have Color TV".   Don't let this frighten you away. One of the last remaining Cafeteria style restaurants or "Hofbrau" this is a wonderful gem.  Daily specials that include lasagna, and prime rib, but also the ever present pastrami or turkey leg is available to you. You can get sides of mashed potatoes, macaroni and cheese and a sourdough roll.  Load up on bread and butter pickles and grainy mustard and you will have a cozy warm meal for around $10. On a cold and foggy San Francisco night this warm comfort food will make you feel at home and could quite possibly be the reason why so many have "Left their Hearts" in San Francisco.

McEpj2MnIG4Y1RkiJEA6_w.review_text: This place was awesome!  Came at lunch time no waiting Tons of meats at a really good price! The Irish coffee was half the price of Bueno vista and just as tasty.   There's 4 of us at this table ... 8 thumbs up

uWvG6NT1WIwRcoIPQZcxfw.review_text: OMG...all I have to say is LAMB SHANKS!!! So tender, the meat just falls off the bone. They also have sandwiches, buffalo stew, salmon, just to name a few. They have huge portions, so make sure you either wear elastic pants or wear a belt w/ extra holes. Service is fast and sufficient. Love the menu w/ all the beers around the world. Oh, and definitely can't pass up the homemade pickles.

Ft1-GegjJKF_wFLb0tbmxQ.review_text: It's actually a 3.5! :) I am not really a big fan of meat but am a sucker for ribs so I decided to try them at Tommy's. It was alright.... I don't really like it when it's too soft and has a lot of juices and that's Tommy's ribs. However it was really not that bad! It's just my personal preference.   THE DRINKS ARE AMAZING!  They had Zombie, Pina Coloda, Bloody Mary, you name it! And it's such a rare find in a joint like this. They have a gazillion beer list. The bartender is very good at his job, and it's CHEAP!  Oh! They even have Tokyo Tea..... dangerous, dangerous drink.   All in all, I will go back to Tommy's. Not really for food though.

xXVHSphY6kA6DS99zFcE5Q.review_text: The food was just unbelievably delicious! I had the round roast dinner plate with mashed potatoes and bakes beans! Also had a pint of Anchor Steam to go with the meal! I need to come back for the buffalo stew and chili!!!

tdbHqXe5oGRy5X9vvAtSeA.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is the real deal. Good basic food that hasn't changed for years. Excellent value for the money regardless of location and this is in downtown San Fransisco. Huge choice of beers from all over the world. This is the perfect place to chow after getting liqueured up, they serve food until about 1:30 AM. BTW - It's also a good choice when sober. Is there better food out there? Sure, but given the price, location and ambiance you'll be hard pressed to do better. About the only complaints I have are the mashed potatoes are a bit salty for my taste and the fact you pay for your food separately from whatever you're drinking. It's not a big deal but it is a bit of a pain.   My best description of the style of food, think of a Sunday afternnoon dinner when you were a kid. My favorite are the roast turkey and brisket, though everything is good.   If in San Fran a must try.  FYI - no credit cards

i-7MtP6jgc1EVwdlnIv2bg.review_text: I know that this place has been reviewed many times. I just want to chime in and say that my first time to this place was great. It's been a while since i've had a great stick to your ribs kinda dinner. The roast beef was tender, the brisket was soft and it was all cheap. I have never gone into Tommys before though i've seen it tons of times. I am so glad i did. NOw i wish  i had all those times i passed it when i was hungry. I tell you this in all seriousness, go there now!! Tons of beers, cheap drinks, plenty of space, and great food. nuff' said

4DM34I6xEqJsdAXcfwmHGg.review_text: We saw this place on DDD and wanted to check it out. I got a beef brisket dinner, and Mike got the prime rib. We ended up switching plates because I liked the prime rib better than the brisket. The portions were large and the prices were decent. The side dishes were mashed potatoes or veggies, and beans or salad and a cold roll.  I wasn't too impressed with the side dishes. Aside from value, I didn't really think there was anything too special about the place. I was surprised that they also had a bar. If I come back, I'll try the other meats.

_1zoBu8_XQ3P_BBChK3gFg.review_text: My Tommy's Joynt Advice (Two Parts)  Part One: Bring cash--it's cash only and the ATM inside is often out of commission, and when it works, it has a fairly high fee.  Part Two: Make your friend act like a volcano twice!  Suppose you have a friend who likes potato salad and he's really sensitive to spicy food.  Tommy's Joynt puts jars of sinus-blasting prepared horseradish (not the weaker creme of horseradish stuff) on all the tables.  Said friend likes to prattle on about miscellanea and at the crazy crap on the walls.  While he goes on and on, suppose you hide a big glob of horseradish in the potato salad, where it remains practically invisible as the horseradish, the potato salad and the plate are all white in color.   Now suppose he eats the potato salad containing the horseradish.  You may just see your friend imitate a volcano.  As he wipes up and buries his face in a napkin, wiping sweat off his brow, you can take a big scoop of hot mustard from another jar (it says "Hot Mustard" on it) and put it in the gravy-filled crater in his mashed potatoes that come along with the BBQ Turkey Sloppy Joe (perhaps one of the best Calorie per dollar values in SF).  Now suppose you recommend he cools the fire of the horseradish with the rich blandness of the potatoes and gravy.  If you've played your cards right once again, he won't see the mustard because it's a very similar golden-brown shade as the gravy, especially in the slightly dim light, and he'll be imitating a volcano again.

bpmbg8eAsBOlUoiZxWzp1A.review_text: When I lived in SF I went to Tommy's once a week. When ever I go back to visit I make sure that I go to Tommy's at least once or twice.  The meals are incredibly filling, the price is cheap, and the food is great. My favorite is the BBQ Brisket of Beef dinner plate.

51f-gzLdOCAeSNyhdXJX6Q.review_text: I've only stopped into Tommy's for a drink. Their drinks are very strong and fairly inexpensive. There was a huge line for food and it smelled amazing. I must come back to try some of their famous sandwiches...

VYSltzpCTJwerN0UDKz11A.review_text: Dear Tommy's Joynt, I LOVE YOU!!!!!   So I pretty much believe anything and everything the food network and travel channel tell me, so when a local sensation pops up, and the BF and I happen to catch it - WE ARE ON IT!   The first time we went, it was around 3PM we found parking on Van Ness a block down. SCORE!   We get inside, and its like Harry's but way cooler, there are a bunch of tables everywhere - and you pretty much sit with strangers, the bar is right there with probably 100 different beers in bottles and FAT TIRE on TAP! SCORE!!!   We order, one roast beef sandwich and one pastrami sandwich - served on the most amazing roll probably sourdough but maybe sour!   We go take a seat. Next to another couple, not like directly next to them - 1 seat in between each of us as were across from each other. The other couple ordered everything Tommy's could possibly offer! But little did we know, they were loaded! Like high off pills, maybe crack - who knows they were falling asleep in their mashed potato's and corn! It was so entertaining.... (that's pretty bad - had to be there)   Anyway, back to our food, Paul ordered the roast beef and I ordered the pastrami - Paul is lucky I agreed to give him half of mine if he gave me half of his! My PASTRAMI WAS GREATNESS!!!!!!   His roast beef was Good - Not GREAT! But good, I love horseradish, and had I remembered to put it on there I bet it would have been better!   Oh and check out the jug of pickles! They are homemade and yummy!   We have been back, random jet to the city and this time Paul orders the pastrami! Me, Bratwurst and Sauerkraut - Such a good German girl!!!! They are open super late at night, and honestly I am determined to hit them up after a night of fun, aka a few beers and wanting great food!   BTW CASH ONLY! Yes they house and ATM machine but it costs like 3 dollars plus the 2 from your bank! LOL

Iovy9ItislQQuQQVYHR1ng.review_text: Honestly, I rate this place a 3.5 but that's not an option.   The decor of this place is EVERYTHING. Seriously just about everything is mounted on the walls, but not in the cheesy Friday's or Applebee's way.   They style of food is served in a very German way with your dinner carved right off the meat.   Portion sizes are huge for the price you pay!   My boyfriend had the bufflo stew (really good) and I had the turkey leg (good but kinda on the dry side, which is odd since it's dark meat).   I would definitely return again, but would want to try something else.

-BLCnU5DzxeXUOFo9_diNg.review_text: I've always wanted to come and sample their meats even before Guy Fieri featured this establishment on his show, "Diners, Drive-in and Dives"! And the moment I walked in, I can see the buzz about this casual and comfortable dining experience!  First thing that hits me wasn't the food, but rather the environment, which is littered with all kinds of antiques and pictures! I heard they have a crazy selection of beer and after walking in, look around and you might spot a wall of bottle to choose from!  Now this isn't a typical sit-and-be-served restaurant. In fact, it's more like a cafeteria type deal. Stand in line and choose from the menu and the meat masters will carve your plate or sandwich. I came with my wife and she got a BBQ Beef sandwich. For myself, I had to try their Brisket!   After paying for your meal, you'll need to find your own table. Tricky, but there will always be a seat for you. Water is self-serve, but sodas and beers can be ordered by their friendly staff that goes around to make sure everything is okay.   Food time! My Brisket was smothered in BBQ sauce, but one thing that I would try is to have the beef juice instead. The BBQ sauce is sweet and tangy and compliments the juicy Brisket well, but the juice would probably take the natural beef flavor out! My wife's BBQ Beef sandwich was tender, but it needed some sauce to moist it up a little more to make it easier to chew on.   Overall, I do see that Tommy's Joynt is a great place to have a meal or a beer. You'll find that there is a lot to explore here in terms of food and all the fun pictures and history that they have around the place, so no matter where you sit, there's always something to look and talk about.

_-9h8TOFMW4AGnVPWbqbIw.review_text: Darn. I expected so much coming to this restaurant. My sister's boyfriend wanted to get some good protein and strengthening food the night before his meet so I found Tommy's Joynt, being hopeful of a large meal and a lot of meat.   I was thoroughly surprised when we walked in and it was all on a booth. It was like a serviced buffet, but not really. You walk in, tell them what you want.. They cut you the "large" (but kind of not that much) portions, routinely dump the sides on your plate, and serve you whatever or however they want. The large glass window barrier that you have to talk behind is difficult to communicate with, but yeah..  The food in itself was interesting. I got the bbq brisket which was quite tender and the meat was very easy to cut through and tear apart. They call it bbq, but you can choose whatever sauce they have. I feel like I should have chosen a different kind since I'm not TOO fond of barbecue sauce. But be warned, once you say you want it, the sauce goes all of your plate. Including over your mashed potatoes. Poop. The potatoes are smooth, kind of reminds me of kfc almost. ONLY kind of. I just think the plate of "bbq brisket, mashed potatoes, bread, salad" was not worth the amount of money we paid. That's all.  The salad was drenched in dressing so about five minutes into the meal, it gets real soggy and just soggy salty lettuce. Which I'm sure many people like....  We sat in the booths towards the back of the restaurant which are not for tiny people. Even for me, it was kind of tight... the tables very close up to your chest and all. Anyway, I honestly think the meal had been ruined by the unfortunate placement of the "no parking" signs just outside the restaurant. You shouldn't put a freaking sign that says no parking (at whatever times) right behind a tree. SF police... honestly... just looking for an excuse to make money : / as sad as that sounds.  Anyway yeah, we were rushed out of our meal just 15 minutes after we had started to eat... poop. Parking tickets suck.

qMFNifOmRQrt1_vUYa15fA.review_text: This place had baddd sandwiches.  How can this place be 4 stars?  Did i order the wrong thing?  I ordered the meat sandwich and the bread was a big puffy roll of hard bland flour slapped with some tasteless meat on it.  I left half of it there when i left.  never again

-dHiOppuk7pLYEqreeGE5A.review_text: I have driven by this place over 50 times as a delivery driver, but never tried it. I saw it on triple D on the food network and said "I am going." My next vacation to the area, the family spent the day in the city, and I told them where we are going to lunch. It looks old and dirty, but it's not. The food was amazing, I had corned beef and cabbage, and my wife had the hot roast beef sandwich. We recieved large portions, and everything was moist and cut to order by the staff right in front of us. My dad, who grew up with home cookin in Nebraska was impressed as well.  They Have a great beer selection if you are into good beer.

Ija7HmWtdypP2P4zYYRnJA.review_text: My one of my favorite places to eat

ZLfvKFwIAexQQOTV3SU6uA.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is a pretty unique dining experience. It's cafeteria style in terms of the order but you can sit down and eat. Wouldn't recommend it if you're vegetarian since it's very meat heavy. But the service is friendly, fast, and the drinks are good too. If you're not TOO hungry, they've got a bunch of inexpensive side dishes that you can snack on. Expected bill is $7.

QE-9s9K-ufaojKldJLXujA.review_text: Very good, simple comfort food. Brisket was very good, but fattier than I care for. Open-faced Meatball sandwich was good, but could have used another meatball - the price was great, and two meatballs was fair, but I'd order an extra meatball. Surprisingly, the mac and cheese is pretty sub-par, until you salt it. It has pepper, which is nice, but literally no other seasoning is detectable. Adding salt makes it okay, but not even as good as I can get at the Safeway Deli counter.

pKqIk1NpORfU6tEDW9S2xQ.review_text: I droped by here for lunch today and it wasnt as great as before.  I ordered the beef brisket and it was tasty and good but cold.  I hate having my food cold so it didnt live to my expectations this time.  The bread is also cold.  Guess i got to go during peak times like lunch.  Its still a deal  for what your getting.  I need to try the other dishes.  Looks like a lot of yummy choices.

Q7ilUe9rNDbXrswScKn41Q.review_text: Another delicatessan seen on Diners, Drive-In's and Dives (or whatev it's called).  Great, great meats made in-house with no BS.  Definitely a must try.  They have daily specials, and although I wasn't there for either of the two days I wanted, it was still well worth it.  Features a full bar as well, so you can plan on spending an entire Sunday afternoon there.

4iJYWTc-aOsfxAtiH735bQ.review_text: A woman's intuition is a very real thing and mine was spot on when it came to Tommy's Joynt.    I knew the first time I saw it on my favorite food network show Diner's, Drive-Ins and Dives and Guy Fieri was raving about how awesome the food was.  I knew when my husband, who never wants to venture out more than a 4-block radius from our job on our hour-long lunch break, suggested we trek from the Marina district and brave the midday traffic of Van Ness on a Friday to try out this SF "joynt".  That never happens so this place had to be pretty special, right?    I pulled up Yelp and checked the reviews and saw that there were 977 total and the overall rating was a 4.5.  Crazy!  I REALLY knew when we were able to find a parking spot just outside the restaurant and even more so when we got to the front door and there was a line spilling down the street.    We finally got in, made it through the line and stood in front of the glass case behind which huge cuts of meat sat under hot lamps waiting to be carved into a veritable feast for our eating pleasure.  I got the turkey just like Guy suggested and a side of rice with gravy and  a roll on the side.  My husband got the beef brisket sandwich.  We got it to go and still made it back to work with 10 minutes to spare.  And I knew.  Had the stars aligned to make this moment possible? Brought together all of the elements so that we could share in this San Franciscan treasure?    I took my first bite and the taste evoked such strong memories of public school cafeteria food that for a moment I could've sworn it was 1985 all over again.  The turkey was dry, the gravy was bland, and I don't think there was one grain of seasoning used on that entire meal.  I used the last 5 minutes of my lunch break to make a bowl of instant oatmeal and it was 100 times better than anything that came out of Tommy's.  My husband said his sandwich was ok but we're both clear on the fact that we'll never darken their hallowed doorway again.  But honestly, what I got was exactly what one should expect from a place like this; steeped in nostalgia and luring in the masses with promises of a meal under $10 in a city where that is surely a rarity.  And despite the rave reviews on both television and the internet that made me hope against hope that this place was different, deep down I knew that going in.  And now so do you.

emzU8YrO82ssahKP7BHxqA.review_text: The food is tasty here and the atmosphere makes for a fun lunch stop while in SF.  Downside for me was - the whole place could use a good cleaning.

cCTUFH4DKPuSuFhbIIcbzw.review_text: this place is aiiiiiight...   ive been here several times, each time the food was OK. all of their food is slow cooked..... so if youre into savory, sloppy, cafeteria style food, this is the place for you. this last time was on a wednesday, the special was bbq ribs.. it really wasnt that special. kind of bland....aND we had to wait in a roller coaster line that zig zagged bak and forth. it was NOT worth the wait.  its cafeteria style, you order, you pay, you get your own utensils and you seat yourselves. i have to mention that they charge you for everythinggggggg....   the decor is very old fashioned. its quite a homey feeling. this restaurant has been here for a very long time. personally, the food doesnt seem all that special, but i think theyre pretty consistent, and there must be something good about them that keeps people coming back all the time. *(I must admit; I havent tried everything....)  I'll update if I come back and things are any different.. =)

suwM7BzyUaFaxALt9kMi0A.review_text: Came in for a quick bite.  Line moved fast.  We shared a pastrami sandwich on a french roll and they gave us a cup of au jus to dip the sandwich in.  It was only 5.75 and the sandwich was delish, from the bread to the carved meat.

OCcHlcwqFtHcKFo5t4UBYA.review_text: This place is like a dream... seriously! I love that I was able to have a really good sandwich and beer for under six bucks. Meat lovers who like their meat slathered in all kinds of oniony/mushroom/bbq goodness would most definitely benefit from visiting. And beer lovers would love the international beer menu. A went here with a friend and she noticed that it was kind of quiet, to which she quipped,"If everyone's quiet, you know the food's good."   I can't wait to come back... I want to try everything on the menu and try every beer ever made!

wZ57iVBf0tXpBMaPZHrEQA.review_text: My dad used to eat here all the time and bring home leftovers, and sometimes he'd take me here. I remember always wanting to try the lasagna, but he would never let me and ordered me other dishes instead. Nevertheless, I was never disappointed! Side note: I used to be an extremely picky eater as a kid! I used to throw away half the ingredients of burgers and various restaurant dishes (sometimes I'd scrape off all the BBQ sauce from ribs...), so this says a lot.  The food here is greasy, greasy, greasy... Yet oh-so-delicious. I always thought that this was an Italian place because they had stuff like lasagna, pasta, enchiladas (which I thought were Italian), etc. I remember trying some of the desserts and I had one of their cookies, that's when I realized that I wasn't going to be a fan of chocolate pudding or jello. The cookie was good, though!  The atmosphere is kinda weird. There's a bar there with a bunch of men watching sports and drinking, probably not the best place to take a kid, but whatever. The lighting is dark, which I really like. I also like sitting in booths! You can always smell the food if you're within a 30ft radius.. Mmm, lasagna...  Decent portions of awesomeness, though I recommend ordering a bunch of stuff and taking bites out of everything :D

ad8cXN5pYhs8EtSUat5WpA.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is DELICIOUS. I'll have to admit I'm a meat and potatoes kind of girl. My brother took me there and I'm dying to go back. Thinking of this place makes me hungry. Upon entering the restaurant the buffet style food is located on your right with a large menu behind the food area. The first thing I noticed was the smell- it smelled like delicious home cooking.  I had the beef brisket, mashed potatoes and sourdough bread. The portions are huge, so I had left overs. Next time I'm going to go on a empty stomach!!!

1Ft0sBM1ujw36PWD27xx5Q.review_text: Meat!  The pastrami is delicious, as is the BBQ brisket of beef, but the roast beef is impossibly chewy and still lowing (that's the sound that cows make, city-folk).    Open until 2am every day.  $8 for meat, mashed potatoes or baked beans and some sort of salad (they have macaroni, potato, green, etc.)  If you're foolish enough to get the green salad, you'll want the dressing on the side - unless you like more dressing than greens.  My only complaint?  Not enough taters.

XX5G1gpBLzv-oXJGlRvfoQ.review_text: If you've liv.. heck, ever gotten drunk in SF, you probably been here.  If you've got the late night snack attack, this is the place to go. However servings are anything but snack size....   I'm from Australia, we call places like these a Carvery. They have giant chunks of roasted meat things and you point at it behind a hot hot glass, and some handsome burly man will carve you a massive piece of meat with some slabs of gravy and choices of vegetables/salad.   Or alternatively you can choose to turn said slabs of meat into a fittingly man-sized big as your face sandwich/roll.   This is exactly that.   Now add on the fact that they server delicious beers.  And delicious homemade pickles, and scoop as much of that stuff as you want they even encourage it.  You are pretty much set.   The beauty of Tommy's Joynt, is that its right on Van Ness & Geary.  You are bound to pass this place on your way home on a night out.  And they know it! They are open late into the night.  So if you get some of that hungry pains at around 10pm and need a man-sized snack, this is the place.    Don't worry, everything will be delicious and worth it here.  Particular highlights, pastrami & beef briskets, these are good.    Hint: Don't use the bathrooms here. Just don't.   And when all is done, you'll need to fulfill the traditions and go across the road to Mel's to get a slice of pie and milkshake to close up your night.

KHhwbBtto8KvS3sXEAxW6g.review_text: Not to be confused with Tommy's Mexican Restaurant, this is a totally different beast entirely. It sits right across the street from a Mel's, so I'm sure the competition is stiff. There are times where lines are out the door for both places. In a push situation like that, I think I'd have to go with Tommy's. It's a meat-eaters dream scenario. The slicers are there cutting through bug portions of Brisket, Pastrami, and a couple other variations of flesh we like to sink our teeth into. You also get a choice of sides with whatever menu entree you choose. Be sure to have a good look, as it's served in a cafeteria style, so keep it moving, we're hungry back here!  DO: Check out the bar, it's fully stocked If at a bar, get there just before closing, perfect for late night! Eat the pastrami  DON'T: Expect many vegetarian dishes Confuse this place with the Mexican Tommy's Let people convince you to go to Mel's instead Expect french fries

NpXYHTX4oB1TD1SBOWdgVg.review_text: I thought this place was pretty good. I went with a bunch of locals who frequented the spot and they advised me to order the brisket, that it was the only good thing to eat so I ordered it.  It was really good, the sauce they put on it was great too. A side of mashers, which were eh and a small plate of beet salad.   We sat down at our table with our food ( as it is served cafeteria style except for drinks) and asked to order drinks and were told that our server was on break and we had to get our drinks ourselves downstairs. I thought that was weird.

I7jbVvYM5vi3QvdG_-uAuw.review_text: It took a while for my friend to convince me to try the self proclaimed 'grubby hole in the wall lunch counter', but after stepping foot in the first time, I felt like I had come home. There is a lunch counter but its constantly filled with turkey,2 types of beef, ham, pork loin and a variety of specials all steaming warm and freshly sliced for your dinner plate or sandwich. and the sides are great as well. i got a huge plate of spaghetti and meat sauce, and my friend got beans and mashed potatoes, all of which tasted good and fresh. we sat at the bar, had one of their many great beers on tap and looked down to realize that everything was $14. $6 for the sandwich, $3 for the pasta and $4 for the beer. It is cash only, but worth every penny. I will be going back for the BBQ Beef sandwich soon!

Ito13b3aPr_8MSCQkfr7NQ.review_text: I've been to Tommy's Joynt so many times I cannot remember.  No really, "I CAN"T REMEMBER."  If you've been out and about in SF on a serious bender with all of your buds and you're all looking for a great place that serves up meat, meat, and more meat then Tommy's is the place for you and the crew!  Go on in and have all of that alcohol inside your gut soaked up with some of the finest cuts of salted meat and slices of excellent breads before heading back to your place and calling it a night that you'll most likely forget part of, if not all of it.  Also, if your looking for beer, beer, and more beer you could hit Tommy's at a different angle and at a much earlier hour too.  Nothin' but choices, choices, and more choices.  Enjoy, I always do :-)

SXfvHWScLghzoTSBqb_e6w.review_text: 532 reviews? what else is there to add on? haha.   seriously, this place is like the ultimate man meal. meat, potatoes, bread, and some green shit that you don't really wanna eat but comes with the meal anyway. they have a HUUUUUGE selection of beers along with a well stocked bar.   i ordered the brisket dinner plate with the cucumber salad, and jesus christ they don't skimp out on the meat! it's so tender that you really don't need a knife at all, you can easily tear it apart with your fork. my friends got the meatball sub and pastrami, all of which was tasty and perfectly done. AND.. it's all under 10$, so you seriously cannot complain.   drinks are also cheap, a large pitcher of heff was 16$ and my tequila sunrise only cost $4.50. side note, they have the cutest little bartender here. he's a small older gentleman who seems really friendly =] the place itself is really old school and quirky, and i kinda like the cafeteria seating. if you're not into that kind of thing, there are booths towards the back of the restaurant.   another side note, there was a super cracked out sf lady that wouldn't get out of the place and basically made our nights.   damn, i love this place.

6kng4nyGuvPFJpXyi-ZIeg.review_text: Dude! What! Ever since this joint was featured on Guys Triple D, I had to try it out. Went here a few weeks ago but I was out of cash, so came back with cash. I hate it when joints don't take cards in this day, but understand its business.  I ordered up the roast beef and this sandwich is humongous. And I can eat. I was stuffed after this meal, and had a hard time getting my azz to work after. The meat was succulent and was in good proportion to the roll size. They even included some aj jous for it. Perfect. Seriously. I need to get back to this place and try some other stuff. The sausage looked super good. This place is Triple D legit, and its located on busy Van Ness too.  Its cafeteria style and you have to find your own seat. I'm not sure how it works when this place is super packed, but it must do well.  Try this joint out. You won't regret it. Oh and prices are very reasonable.

BkS9k6g_IwLb4Qjx4ycAww.review_text: What's the word for "beyond legendary"?  Legendary-plus?  Ultra-legendary?  If you dine here, be aware that there are people in every continent except Antarctica talking at that very moment about how they wish they were at Tommy's Joynt.  Highlights?  The huge honking chunks of various animals (sorry Bambi) sliced to order, plus things like lamb stew, buffalo chili, turkey legs, etc..  Oh yeah, and the world-wide beer selection.  And the fact that the same guy has been at the cash register for like 20 years every single minute they're open.  Lowlight: the tough, leathery sourdough rolls.  You can't chew them, you can't cut them, but you can use them for self-defense purposes -- the outside corner can get pretty questionable late nite....

-lY8yFyauUdJd0r6eozxrA.review_text: This place is great!!! The food is DELISH, not heavy at all and very reasonably priced. The service is good too, they are very friendly and always have a smile! Easily one of my favorite Joynts in San Francisco!

9A58ZhWUObzvb-bybheNkQ.review_text: I love this place - even though it is pretty limited fare I get the same things all the time:  The Meat Balls and spaghetti (you can see the greasy residue)... and the beef dip sandwich with side of potato salad rank high on my list of usual grub here.  My wife usually springs for the turkey dinner plate as her homage to a "healthy" option here - which I approve of with the thick and flavorful stuffing!  SIgh... gotta go back again SOON.....!

53vZluQcvw7g5b6NtzUWig.review_text: I'm having a hard time giving Tommy's Joynt only two stars ... it may be because: 1) a guy took me here on a first date, where he 2) was a regular, and  3) watched the Giants game instead of talking to me.  I have to say, I was secretly excited to dine here because I am a fan of DDD but because of the above, I wasn't all that excited.  I had the veal that was a special that night with a side of rice.  I thought I would get a salad included but should have known better being at a hof brau and all - duh, me!    Believe it or not, I would want to come back here again - not a first date though!  I'd opt a sandwhich or something a little meater and not be surprised when I don't get any veggies.

sOzeK0dE0BYx4Mc8dmoenQ.review_text: I've been to TJ several times. Used to live two blocks away. It's always been a comfort to walk over and grab my favorite beer from Peru( Callao).   I like eating in a communal style setting every once in a while. So this joint suits me just fine.    I go here for the beer and the corned beef. A meal after a movie a couple of blocks away is awesome. Don't expect a fancy sit down place people- this is not the place.   This is a low maintenance, non pretentious place to sit and mingle while you chow down. Or just eat and not mingle if you're not feeling that social.  But TJ is a SF landmark. So that's one reason to drop by.

Ff2ltip33PhPSj8iQuOswQ.review_text: Stopped in here because I found parking right around the corner.  I was not disappointed.  The sandwiches were HUGE & the prices small & the quality great!!  My husband had the lasagne, I had the roast beef & my daughter had the pastrami, her boyfriend had the turkey sandwich & coleslaw...it was all great but we could have split the sandwiches and still been full.    There was a short line that moved quicky, but the traffic was constant...the only odd thing was you had to order your drinks at the bar which is on the opposite side.

7M_6FojGZNbT3ZJt_wrV-A.review_text: What a staple, good ole Tommy's. Roasted, stewed, and braised meats, oh my. Turkeys, cows, and pigs, oh my. Beef meatballs, turkey legs, and shanks of lamb, oh my. Great prices, buffet style line, and cozy atmosphere.

fZxazDhgaQMHeV4Xsb-h_w.review_text: I've always passed by this place, but never knew what it was, but I'm glad I do now.  I got the lamb shanks and for just under $8, I got a helluva meal.  The shanks fell right off the bone and melted in my mouth.  Vegans, stay away.  You should know better.

csJB5kjZXAgWpN5h6y3sMQ.review_text: I surprisingly spent a lot of time at Tommy's Joynt the four years I lived in San Francisco.  It is a restaurant unlike any other (well, aside from Lefty O'Doul's) in that it is a cafeteria style meat fest which you can smell from a block away.    Despite ordering side dishes, you should know that eating at Tommy's Joynt means you'll be eating meat, bread and maybe mashed potatoes. My friend told me she once ordered the cheese sandwich and she received a slice of cheese between two pieces of bread.  In other words, plan on getting meat in one form or another.  Tommy's has a full bar and impressive beer and drink menu.  They'll gladly make you any kind of silly tropical drink or spiked coffee and I feel their prices are rather inexpensive. I specifically liked it when Jay was behind the bar.  He, like all of Tommy's staff are so nice!  Another tip about Tommy's Joynt:  It is one of San Francisco's best places for people watching.  You'll never find a better spot that brings so many different types of people together!  Between their steady elderly clientele, the locals who come in to watch sports (I was at Tommy's Joynt when the Giant's won their 2nd to last World Series game.  The place exploded!) and visiting tourists, Tommy's is a revolving door of interesting characters that give a good representation of SF's population.  Well, meat eating population...

XI6H8T2gF5Ujvf3K4rUWvg.review_text: Did you see the movie "300"?  Godalmighty!  It was a bad-ass kick-fest to the highest degree!  You got like 300 fierce Greeks servin' up a big can of whoop-ass to the Persian army... slather on oceans of blood and you've got yourself an Academy Award winner if voters were all 14-year old prepubescent boys.  The best (and absolutely cornball) line in the movies is "...eat a hearty breakfast men, for tonight WE DINE IN HELL!!!!!!!!!"  This would be the perfect segueway to a meal at Tommy's Joynt.  This place is so cheezeball and basic, they misspell the name on purpose!  It's an ancient, creaky, shanty of a building where some of the stains on the floor are older than my parents.  It's a place so heinous that my wifey would choose to be fondled by 300 smelly vagrants than to ever set foot inside.  In short, Tommy's is a place I dearly love.  Where else can you get a stick-to-your ribs meal that fills your stomach to the point of explosion for under six bucks?  The food is "great" and your chances of food poisoning have got to be less than fifty-percent...  Anything with turkey is their specialty.  I don't know why they chose to honor this ugly bird, but they sure do roast it well.  The open-faced turkey sloppy Joe is a little bit of heaven in this Hellish place.  You can't go wrong with the roast beast either, it's fiiiiine!!!  To sum things up: If you've got the appetite of a blood-thirsty, crazed Greek warrior, then Tommy's Joynt is for you.  "Prepare for Glory!!!"

R5lhVvcJ7tNx9-Pe2-j8Pg.review_text: This place is A-OK! taste-wise, BUT, because of their enormous portions and low prices, yay!, I'm a fan!!1  The my-future-wifey and I both got the sloppy joes. Lately we have been discussing sharing plates at restaurants so we don't overeat. This would have been the perfect opportunity to start implementing that. Except we didn't and we both ate our enormous turkey sloppy joes. We left very full. When we got home we both passed the Fck out.  I wanna come back soon and do it all overrr again.

aBYNZvs3aO0WNcRnTu5HJA.review_text: Hof Brau SF style.    Go when they have lamb shank or sweet sour ribs as their special.  If you just want to order off  of the carving station, get some roast beef, or brisket, a heaping pile of meat awaits you.  To the people who complain about waiting in line cafeteria style, Get a life!!  thats part of the experience.  TJ's 4 life!!!!!!!!

0juzbrgcLHqobdK-OZAyiw.review_text: Tommy's Joynt has been around forever and highly noticeable given its extremely colorful exterior and can't miss location on the corner of Geary and Van Ness. Fellow Yelper Tom R and I were still hungry after having brunch at a nearby restaurant so we decided stop by Tommy's to see what they're all about. The restaurant is partially a lunch line steamed table hof-brau combined with a sport bar and heavily decorated with sports memorabilia and an impressive collection of empty bottles and cans to fill the antiquated wooden décor from floor to ceiling. The place was crowded and festive all around, and we were expected to share a table with a few others with plenty of eyes glued to two big TV screens with Cal playing Duke in the second round of the NCAA Tournament.  Tom was very gracious to treat me to a bowl of Buffalo Stew ($7.95) which came with generous chunky buffalo serve in a savory stew covering a soft bed of white rice underneath. The meat and the bread that came on the side were dry after it's been heated all day, but the savory sauce was tasty to combine with the rice to hit the spot. It was a solid round of comfort food and the rest of the menu that included the likes of sandwiches, salads, clam chowder, sausages and desserts are affordable and accessible for locals and tourists alike. From what I've seen on other people's plate, portions were very generous all the way around.  Service was quick and responsive at the steamed table and the overall environment was very pleasant with a friendly crowd. I would definitely be interested in visiting them again whenever I'm in the Van Ness area. 3 stars for the solid experience.

17e5W0HaRJ2kgQApt_5wHw.review_text: Food I give 3 stars.   Atmosphere I give a solid 4 stars.  We ordered buffalo stew , spaghetti and meatballs, coleslaw.  It was tasty, but the spaghetti was overcooked (kinda like chef boyardee).

6KWq2nOYOv3VJP4gKx6vNA.review_text: We were driving LA to SF that day and were looking for a spot to eat. Tommy's Joynt was recommended by a friend who lives in CA. Food was amazing, The process to get it is a bit odd...but I like it. Wait in line. Pay cashier in cash only and then find your own seat and get your own drink from the bar or waitress. Meatball sammy was great as was the Pastrami sammy with au jus. My girlfriend had the bbq brisket which was also amazing. Thoroughly enjoyed Tommy's.

1IEjfmsxU05v-NBOs0NFkg.review_text: Definitely a man eating spot with nothing but lotsa of bloody meat. I love that fact this place is open late night. I am often here a group of guy friends at 12a eating a massive pile of meat that puts me to sleep like the ape that I am. Atmosphere is worth checking out even you're a vegetarian. Be warned though, you may get nauseous at the site.   Missing one star for the cartilage I bit into once. Its inevitable.

s-gcpca9f6ufDfq77LyT4A.review_text: Always a good experience, very reasonably priced food, and a fun environment..  It's not dull, always a diverse crowd, quick food prep.  The food tastes great! Yeah, it can be unhealthy, but... what do you expect? They serve alcohol, have cool art up on the walls..  minus one star for parking.

uZg1FZbO99YnX61Hw3fd3Q.review_text: I'm kicking myself for not visiting this place sooner. You'll walk out full and satisfied for less than $10 (no drink).  Complimentary pickles!    Theodore O. aka "Pastrami King" got it right about their pastrami.  I was considering a pastrami sandwich but opted for the dinner plate which came with veg, mash, salad, and bred roll.  $9 and some change.  The hand carved pastrami was delicious.    Its cafeteria style and that's cool with me but some of our female friends weren't such big fans of it.  Boo hoo for them! More pastrami for me!

90JTCrrA5F6BhA8_grBoEQ.review_text: Got the pastrami plate with a beet salad and a cheesecake. The meat was very tender and flavorful I wish I had got more, but with the side salad and desert it was plenty of food. The beet salad was a little overpowering, and the cheesecake wasn't special.  Convenient place if you're in the area, but nothing I would go out of the way for.

iqmkrOQYGIyxhi4tW_dhMA.review_text: Went there tonight, cuz I hadn't been there in like 10 years and friend had never been there. I love this place! I had the corned beef dinner, OMG, couldn't have been any better!  Very satisfying and filling and comforting, yeah, I liked it a lot! Friend had the buffalo chili and she loved it!  She really liked the fact that they serve good butter with the rolls!!! The drinks and beer selections are amazing. I would suggest this place for anyone looking for good, solid comfort food. YUM!

7du0PgQr3C9Ae85Df7o7fA.review_text: Good comfort food.  Buffalo stew and Pastrami are tops.  Will go again again and again. Lots more to try. Great selection of bottled and draft beer too.

w50dmF3VAHrXPJQbqXfdYg.review_text: This was one of my first dinners in SF and I really loved it. OK, well maybe my taste buds have gotten more sophisticated since then - I mean this is not gourmet food, but something about the place still really appeals to me. Huge portions, low prices, good meat, and a nice balance of whole in the wall & clean. Lot's of tasty meat if you want a protein binge...

QGlEMJ3KaYi4IzVKlnLPpw.review_text: This place is great if a tad divey. You stand in a line and get tasty food at a pretty good price. The stuffing and sandwiches is wonderful! The only downside is they only take cash so remember to bring some or you'll need to use the in-restaurant ATM. Those always charge too much.

zIcQhhS-GAsivm9XI0Il0Q.review_text: This place is really overrated. The Irish Coffee was terrible, the sandwich was nothing special. More of a tourist trap than anything.

zt8VHhyV3ugxNVhqHwScog.review_text: Awesome food!!! Great prices,lots of beer on tap,daily specials...classic joint.

wq558scpW-X8PecmJ-sD9w.review_text: I love this place for a good, basic hot sandwich.  I usually go in, take a look at the meat, and pick whichever looks the juiciest and best that day.  I have had the barbeque brisket, ham, corned beef, and pastrami.  All are awesome and I seriously choose what to eat by which is dripping/steaming/calling me the loudest.  I suggest you do the same.  You won't be dissapointed

ilesK4CRarjiblkxUDL_tQ.review_text: Eating a Kielbasa sausage on a bun with a beer is considered a light meal at Tommy's Joynt! The plates are gigantic and the prices are very reasonable.   I love the atmosphere and the cheap beer :)

c8qlnglgNgqsJFWygkNt7w.review_text: Edible on a late night but nothing memorable. : (  I was recommended this place by a co-worker and the food fell flat. Kind of like the food you got when you were in school, warm, small portion, and bland. Hubby and I left (even with carrot cake dessert) still hungry and craving something truly satisfying. Needless to say I would not go back.

P9tsVSYF79fwRvMEjtTvWg.review_text: 3rd time here in years.  hasn't changed. inexpensive & they take food & drink seriously here.   i love buffalo.  had buffalo sandwich & chili.  sandwich is buffalo stew on bread.  big chunks of meat.  cool arabic cooks.  strong long island ice tea for less than $7.  fun decor .   i could be a regular, at least twice per week.

-0IiMAZI2SsQ7VmyzJjokQ.review_text: As the cook pulled out a big piece of corned beef, he just continued to cut slice after slice, pulling out more hunks to cut up and pile on my plate. "Is he going to stop now?" I thought. He just kept slicing up more pieces for my meal before dropping on a mountain of mashed potatoes.  It's $9 for a feast (cash only).   My boyfriend, being a huge Metallica fan, occasionally remarked on an interest in going to Tommy's whenever we were in the area. However, we would always forget or didn't have internet access to look up whichever Tommy's Hetfield and the boys would nosh at. Thankfully our hostel had free wifi, so we Yelp'd that shit.   But yeah, they give you A LOT of food with your choice of meat, whether you want mashed potatoes or vegetables, beans or salad (I don't really recommend the potato salad, especially if you got mashed spuds on top on that, as the tater salad is pretty bland), and a big sourdough roll with butter. The rolls were great for soaking up juices from the meat.   The boyfriend couldn't help but head upstairs and take a quick picture of the bathroom where James, Lars, and Kirk told Jason Newsted he was in, following the death of previous bass player Cliff Burton. It was empty, of course.  In every way, this place rocks. Great food, great vibe, great place for dorks like us to geek out on some metal history.

bvwYD6VmBH5VfdEWDFa_PA.review_text:
My housemates are such lovely people. They wanted to take me out on the town and to go see the Borat movie, because they said, "When you laugh, it makes us laugh." I wan't sure how to take that. Like, what, I have a funny laugh? I don't think I do. I mean, it's kind of loud. But not annoyingly so. I don't snort or make honking sounds. I just laugh. They said, I make them happy. Okay, fair. So you guys are paying for everything, right?
  The movie was sold out, so we decided to go to eat at Tommy's Joynt. The line was ridiculous. But it moved quickly enough. My eyes glazed over, and I was seeing red - pasta sauce, pickled beets, meats meats meats. I didn't know what to order. The buffalo stew is delicious, I know that. I've had their bratwurst before. Mmm! I ended up going for rack of lamb, with small boiled potatoes, served in a very salty gravy sauce. I got a side order of pickled beets, and my housemates ordered me a Sierra Nevada. They each had martinis, from which I ate all the olives. I smiled happily. The lamb was so tender and very salty and I ate a whole lot of it. Both of my housemates ordered burgundy beef, which was also quite good.
  The best part about Tommy's is the crowd. There was a couple there with a wailing child. The mother looked barely older than the kid. She had a distinct Slavic accent. The father was this balding, much older man, with a bit of a beer gut and thick glasses. He was distinctly American. The wife spoke to the kid sternly, "Zet is vy you should never hev children - zey vill be like you!" (Awesome!). She didn't look happy to be there. I said, in a hushed tone, "You guys, I bet you anything that she's a mail order bride." Here she comes to this country, thinking life will be magical, and ends up married to some fat shlub who takes her on romantic outings to Tommy's Joynt, with its beer flags and license plates and deer heads tacked up on every possible surface. But hey, the food's all right. America is a country that likes its gravy. She cannot complain about lack of fatty meats!

Gjq554OYiO7qJCbmoGKSMA.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is the place to go when you're looking for delicious food that will fill you up at affordable prices. It's one of San Francisco's food institutions.  I've been going there for a while now and the food has never disappointed. I usually get the meatball sandwich, which is out of this world. The sauce for the meatballs and the meatballs themselves are some of the best I've ever had. Another favorite of mine is the buffalo chili. It comes with beans and buffalo over a mound of rice and it's a great meal that is also reasonably priced.  It's a fun atmosphere and it certainly has an old school atmosphere to it which makes the experience even better.

kUhKJ-op-E_CHZQsq3SaGg.review_text: Try some Buffalo Stew , I was introduced to this place in the late 70's and its stil nice to go and have some Ol Hof Brau style food. Bring CASH!!

Sw21xB3CxHUCtQDZwzPjyA.review_text: I went there and was pretty satisfied. I had the BBQ beef brisket. I really like the beer list.  The ambiance is cool. I would give it 4 stars if the waitress was a little more attentive.

fSvOdnryI9FPJ2ylcsE2ig.review_text: Who knew this type of place existed in SF? I think I've probably driven by this place a thousand times and never really noticed it before.  I only went because my brother knew about it and of course he knew about it because he's a guy in his mid-twenties and loves hearty food. I've been to Harry's Hofbrau in Santa Clara and Foster City numerous times, but it's so much easier having one in the city.  I ordered the corned beef and it includes mashed potatoes or veggies and a side salad, plus bread for $8.50. Yeah, not too bad, huh! I wish they had cabbage with corned beef though and it was salty, as corned beef usually is. There was more than enough food, and I didn't finish. We were lucky that when we went, there were about 3 people ahead of us...I think the line soon went out the door.  Just be advised, they only take cash, so make sure you have enough! They also have a full service bar up front, which looked pretty crowded with the basketball game on the flatscreen.

ilLF-v5PmjEE6zkYnSrE_Q.review_text: I Like places that are cafeteria style. Tomm'ys did not disappoint. After an appetizer at fisherman's wharf(fried shrimp and calamari) Me and Scotty chose the bbq beef sandwich and dinner plate. I had a side of the famous buffalo chili. I loved it. The bbq sauce is nothing like i have ever had. The chili was also tasty. It had the perfect balance of beans and meat. The bread they use is fluffy on the inside with a perfect crust on the outside.  So far Guy has not steered me wrong!

rJ5mJ18V-2fjW_5OkeHnng.review_text: Whenever I come into this place I always feel like I'm in Kansas City or Pittsburgh. This place has that Midwestern kind of feel to it but regardless of how it looks the food is good and affordable. I usually always get the beef brisket sandwich on sour dough roll for $7. Hard to beat that price.

JEvUHDBSgfzTO9ysH4Jc4w.review_text: I did not know places like this existed in San Francisco! And for such cheap prices too. I've seen this place a million times while on the 38L down geary but I hadn't ever been in because Van Ness is never a destination for me. My friends decided to come here tonight though and I happily walked down from Japantown to check it out.  Cheap (but *cash-only*) hauf brau style food? Awesome. And an extensive bar too? SWEET. All my okie/texan roots were showing for sure, and it helps that I am pretty enthusiastic about food from the german culture as well.  I had the polish sausage sandwich and a side of cucumber salad which tallied up to a grand total of $6.02. Pretty good. I wish I could have gotten the mashed potatoes but I have been trying hard to at least attempt to eat more of my green vegetables. Both were pretty satisfying, not particularly fancied up, but basic and good. Although now that I am at home, I'm pretty sure I had too much cucumber salad, cause my tongue hurts...and my love-hate relationship with all things vinegar'd and pickle'd continues.  In a city that often caters to foodies and the hyping-up of traditional cuisines and fusion foods (which also drives price and snooty-ness levels through the roof) it's nice to know that down to earth places with character are still alive and well.

-h0iYeye2TaByPg-yS2zaA.review_text: I had their buffalo chili. The food was okay and reasonably priced. They also have really cheap stuff like four dollar pasta. Overall not that impressive like what I've heard.

K8cVrkmyM2lTwR9froinpQ.review_text: A San Francisco landmark, right smack dab in the intersection of two of SF's biggest trans-city arteries.  I can't imagine Van Ness Ave without this beacon of tradition brightening up the street.  I think I first ate here when I was about 7 years old.  You can get lost in the sea of garagesale-esque memorabilia decorating every square inch of the walls and ceilings.  Not to be sexist, but I think this is definitely more of a MAN's place to eat with it's unsophisticated and gritty hof brau-type atmosphere (well at least in my experience the ladies seem a bit daunted by the whole scene).  The food is simple and the beers are plenty.  The meat is excellent and all the sandwiches I've had are nothing more than a cut of meat on a plain white roll.  The roll functions like a sponge to soak up all the juice from the meat.  Delicious.

lktvZdRSa1zqxYcaL0-Dsw.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is about the experience. It's one of the oldest and most beloved restaurants in San Francisco, a place that my grandparents used to enjoy eating at. The Hofbrau set up is a bit unorthodox in this day and age but I dig it. Don't be discouraged by the line, it moves quickly. All you have to do is wait in the queue, come up to the hot food counter, pick your meal and have it placed on a tray, gather your own utensils, find your own table, and dig in. The only wait staff you will see are the cocktail waitresses, who circle around for your convenience.   The decoration is very nostalgic with dive bar and old school sensibilities. A no frills time warp that's clean enough to feel comfortable dining in. The tables in front tend to fill up fast so your best bet is to travel upstairs if you don't want to sit next to strangers. They're open late, they've never run out of anything I've wanted, and there are usually some prime people watching opportunities.   While no one will be giving them a Michelin star any time ever, they dish up classic American comfort food that caters to carnivores. This place is always crowded so there is great turnover. They serve a variety of sandwiches, dinner plates, and sides at extremely affordable prices and in huge portions. The BBQ brisket and corned beef dinner plates are main attractions and the pastrami sandwich is your safe bet. I particularly like the horseradish and the hot mustard in terms of condiments. The hickory baked beans and mac and cheese sides are standard by themselves but  tasty when you combine them. The salads are not their specialty but the one with cucumbers in apple cider vinaigrette is decent. Definitely get a complimentary, housemade pickle to go with your meal, especially if you get a sandwich.   If you're looking to hang out here for awhile, the alcoholic beverage offerings are a must. They've got bottled beers from all around the world, cheap pitchers, and fairly strong mixed drinks. The house margarita is unbeatable in terms of bang for your buck. Getting your own drinks from the bar is far superior to ordering from cocktail waitresses because they urge you to pay on the spot so unless you happen to have exact change, chances are you could be waiting awhile for them to come back.   Don't forget to bring cash and a serious appetite.   Side note, the erotic novelty dispensers in the bathrooms are ridiculous!

JVpmdiQ5EpuPbqUrLmtHew.review_text: Kinda grimy, but love it when I'm in the mood for some good hearty, down-and-dirty food.  Huge fan of braised ox tails on Mondays, and the lamb shanks on Thursdays (which were featured on the Food Network!)  Staff is no-nonsense and friendly :)

6L-VcXwxYtXjmyKKRTNLkA.review_text: "Quality meats and good beers" We enjoyed turkey, pastrami and brisket washed down with some good beers and wine. You don't come here for fine dining but the meats were excellent and the price hard to believe. Suggest you try it for yourself.

CvWvdjHW8WqxKULqVi82Fw.review_text: Open til 2am everyday. Perfect pick me up when you're wasted or just need comfort food. Order the bbq brisket meal. It has every type of beer or liquor you could ever dream about. Good when sober, even better when drunk. Cheap food which has never let me down. I give places like Tommy's and Joe's of Westlake 5 stars because of their atmosphere, consistency, and no yuppies allowed vibe.

g1Kr6K27oNY47xxeSTyo2w.review_text: I was expecting more and didn't get it.  You walk in and there's a little buffet line with three guys behind it trying to rush you through and ask you what you want.  I asked them what the best thing they serve is and they pointed me towards the BBQ Beef sandwich.  The beef itself was nice and tender, however, all you get is sliced beef on a piece of dry bread.  The price was good - only $6 for the sandwich.  In terms of the environment, it was really a dive.  The booths were broken and table tops were sticky.  All in all, it was ok, but not worth making a special trip for.  There are much better food options in SF.

R4A3pN76bflAgolJqAHRNA.review_text: I'm a big fan of Tommy's Joynt menu and pricing where you can get a big helping of chow for approx $7.  Just remember try not to set your expectations too high.  The food is ok/good but don't expect to enjoy a Le Cordon Bleu fine dining experience.   The building, floors and tables are old school with lots of history but the facilities certainly show their age.  Pros:  Good hearty food at bargain prices.  Cons: Not great food, cafeteria style ordering, self seating, sometimes strange characters enjoying a meal next to you.

NOUfyJW-BAo_-Cbfo8edww.review_text: Talk about old school and basic. The place looks old and dark inside with a bar, long tables, red checkered tablecloths, and older manly guys standing by ready to carve meat. The menu is what you'd expect, meat, deli salads, potatoes, cookies, and pies. Prices are low.  * Pastrami sandwich ($5.75 + 80 cents extra for Swiss cheese): Comes with your choice of bread. The meat is smoky and savory with a beautiful dark char, carved into thick slices, with luscious flavor. However the sandwich was really plain -  ordinary white bread slices with hard crusts, mayo, mustard and cheese. It would be nice with something like pickles, coleslaw or horseradish. The pastrami could use a spice/pepper crust.  Cash only.

mSxHHZ9XifErXXFHvVaFew.review_text: When I'm in the mood for a hearty sandwich or wholesome plate of meat, potatoes, and vegetables in a very casual place, Tommy's always delivers.  You can't go wrong with the brisket plate or brisket sandwich with a very thin BBQ sauce, more of a gravy really.  The corned beef and cabbage, outstanding.  Other sandwiches like pastrami and corned beef are also great.  The baked beans are tasty.  Not a huge fan of the mashed potatoes there.  Tons of basic salads there that are fine.  I like the cucumber and onion salad.  The carrot cake is awesome.  And a great selection of beers.  They serve very late.  Great for a quick dinner when in that hood or for some late night grub after drinking on Polk street.

ZqEW0hByiV8PtMvHS00OIw.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is a carnivore's wet dream. On occasion I find myself randomly craving large, medievalesque slabs of animal and find myself here; where burly, mustached artisans crave up meaty goodness with long, sharp blades (which can probably double for personal protection in a pinch; drunk douche-bags beware).   Your meal is rounded off with your choice of salad or beans; mashed potatoes or veggies; and a roll to make such carnivorous consumptions conscionable. All for the low price of $9. And all of it is delicious.   The roped off bread line right at the entrance moves at an even click. A full bar offers ample options to wash down your meal. Picnic tables downstairs, upstairs seating, and plenty of bar space means you'll never wander with your heavy trail of vittles for want of parking space.   I never met Tommy but I like him and his Joynt. That's a hand I'd like to shake.

ujgXQiiGBJRVHqTOTJZCnQ.review_text: Some of the best sandwiches in San Francisco and the best Pastrami anywhere! I usually get the Pastrami on Sourdough, always fantastic! The sandwiches are just bread and meat which I like. I've also tried the Ham and Roast Beef. Both were really great as well, but there's just something about that Pastrami. I've lived in SF for almost 2 years now and have eaten here more than any other palace because the food is so good, especially the Pastrami. A nice place to go to watch a Giants or 9'ers game too. They have an excellent beer selection at the bar. I cannot recommend this place enough if you're in San Francisco. You really must try a Pastrami on Sourdough.

j0eBR4rcbtpylG6b47TD7Q.review_text: As a Frisconian, I definitely have a strong appreciation for Tommy's Joynt. It's a classic joynt...a San Francisco treat, to both locals and out-of-towners. You can't miss the aroma of meat radiating around that busy corner. They have they staple menu, and a changing menu. It's kinda hit-or-miss with the quality of dishes on the changing menu, but I'm satisfied most of the time. Finding a seat with that heavy-ass try can be a bit of a struggle, even more difficult when I stop at the pickle barrel to stock pile pickle slices on my plate. It doesn't matter what I order, I gets me some pickles!

BZ7-KLbNuNN1cO0U_WyRAQ.review_text: Cafeteria style place.... Amazing brisket,maybe  the best I've had. Coleslaw was great too. Don't bother with clam chowder,  it's thickened with flour not cream. I've has as good out of a can. All of the meats looked amazing.

wdvDGI_gVlGfHhrB01LrzQ.review_text: Meh, the food here is decent - typical hofbrau faire. The people behind the hot food bar are cold and sterile as far as customer service goes, but there's a good bit of nostalgia and San Francisco history here. I had high expectations about this place, but I'm underwhelmed.   Maybe sometime I'll say wow.

o2UkwgSKx8i-YtUtDD5vNg.review_text: So I had the turkey BBQ sloppy Joe. I'd say it was almost just an open-faced sandwich. There was no way to eat this thing without a fork. The turkey part was delicious. But it was super sloppy, duh! and I was thinking it would have smaller chunks of turkey so that I could actually eat it like a sandwich. It came with a side of mashed potatoes, which were like the kind you'd get at a school cafeteria, but since they were smothered in gravy, they tasted alright.  The meatball sandwich looked good. My friend had that. Messy, too. I'd say that unless you get a dinner plate, you're going to have a meaty, messy meal.   It was more than I could finish, and it was only $4.95. That's a great price. The chocolate chip cookies you can buy prewrapped were actually pretty tasty... yes, I saved room for that small dessert, what of it? All that was left of my meal, anyway, was some very soggy gravy-covered pieces of bread....

sXKmP90GCdF0oM0AzYRhaQ.review_text: Came here quite a few times with friends (should really come with friends to try out their crazy array of carnivorous dishes)   Shoosh, I don't eat meat, but I CRAVE for their crazy variery of beers! I enjoy sitting on that end family table and enjoying my beer and vintage Asahi poster with the super old school hairstyle the lady model has on. Okay just kidding, but they have a serious collection of beer plates and posters all over their walls and celling.   They should really consider installing a heater in their restrooms upstairs. The place is freeziinnggg.  I love the people there, especially the ones behind the bar. Very cute older men who love to chat if you start chatting with them.  Pickles are always free, but don't be too greedy and waste food.  Opens till 2 am. Great late night snack shack if you don't really care about calories or being fat and crap.

kap-a51yfAh4HeJFlHMS7A.review_text: Cheap alcohol, cheap food, and casual hangout spot.  Came w/ my girls 2 weeks ago.  After drinking a bit, we felt like munchies, so we went to the line to order some food.  I think it tasted better after alcohol, but I've had the food when sober and they were not bad as well.  Prob. depends what you order.  The pasta tends to get a bit soggy, but their chili was good.  Pasta sauce was good though.  They have all sorts of beer which we liked, and we also ordered some shots.  When we paid fr the shots, we were quite shocked.  It was like $6 for hennessey.  And it looked like a triple shot to us.  We just couldnt blv it.  Think we are coming back again one of these nights.  Parking aint that bad either.

z7KsQ_nfTZq6mm6ZPAk_Mg.review_text: Good food that is open late. The brisket was delicious.

u58FjSNB9K9ST_FQ5SAT3g.review_text: My parents LOVE this place - probably the stiff drinks.  I think it's okay, it's probably the cafeteria style serving that turns me off.  To be fair, $6 for a good sandwich is a deal.  My turkey sandwich was just okay, it was a little dry and all they had was pickles and mustard to add to it.  My husband had the BBQ beef sandwich, and we both agreed that it was really, really good.  I would come back to Tommy's for that.  The mashed potatoes tasted like they were made from a box, but I could be wrong.  it's a serve yourself kind of place, but the bartender came around once in awhile to see if we wanted drinks.  Because I know I'll be coming back with my parents I'll say that I wouldn't mind eating here again - but over all I would rather try other places.

q35o54dDJ5ciM2M3F5DRRA.review_text: Has Anthony Bourdain ever been here? If not, I'd have to slap him if he walked in the door. And then dip him in gavy... And then... Oh! Sorry.  This place is super old school and although the meat-counter looks gritty, I've never had bad food here.

WXWiigA3gSikIBtcN3yseQ.review_text: I had Tommy's Joint three times. First time, was a dine in. Service was okay but was very busy. Second and third times the food gave me the runs.   I don't understand the reviews here. It's literally cafeteria food with outrageous prices here. Lamb and turkey was dried, I thought I was eating jerky. The tri tip sandwiches looked amazing but tasted bland when I ate it. That caused my stomach to brew tea. In and out of the toilet all night. Yuck

91SN7LzUrC0oKE4lM90v3w.review_text: I was skeptical when I was told this restaurant's claim to fame was that Metallica used to eat there. I was like....so? I pretty soon changed my tune with one bite of the succulent ox-tail meat that literally fell off the bone (yeah, it was THAT tender!) on a Monday lunch break. This led to further investigative munching which led to the discovery of the beef ribs on Tuesday and Baby-backs on Saturdays. I'm so hooked now that I am ashamed to take my (vegetarian) parents out dining on weekends in that area because I am always tempted to tempt them. Every good thing I ever heard about Tommyz Joint is under-reported.. You simply HAVE to go see 4 yourself. Adios muchacha mu-munchies!!!!

4nVyXm6PDzpSm8aoqNnz6g.review_text: Chill place to get some grub, GREAT beer selection somewhere in the neighborhood of 60 beers...the only real knock on the place is the service, it seems like every time I go in there the waitress is either new or reeeeeeally slow. The bartenders are so-so...I've had a couple of times that I order a beer listed on their board they don't have. The waitresses don't seem to know what beers they have. The food's pretty good, haufbrau-style grub. It's especially good on a cold day/night for some hearty food for a decent price. Sundays they have all the football games on, I usually go eat there before the 9ers games (the bus-stop is directly across the street). Great for a beer & meal before the game!  FYI - Cash only.

BvjkbQU_5tXtU7fgVCiZiA.review_text: Wanted to write a quick follow-up to my food poisoning experience @ Tommy's. I received a very nice email via Yelp from the owner of Tommy's shortly after my initial post. I was indeed the person who called the Health Dept. as he'd rightfully guessed. My illness was just wretched. I wanted to make sure no one else had to experience the same. The owner reconfirmed my suspicions that the plate of sliced dill pickles I consumed was most likely the culprit. I'm not sure how I missed the public pickle barrel on my previous visits. Apparently since the place opened they've had a huge barrel where anyone could reach in and  grab themselves a pickle. Our visit was late on a Saturday night and I was informed that many people over the course of Thursday, Friday and Saturday had used the barrel. Tommy's apparently provides tongs or something as a suggested method for pickle procurement but it's only a suggestion not a hard and fast rule. Our waitress had gone into that public barrel and sliced up a couple pickles for our table.   Anyway, it boils down to contaminated pickle juice...  No matter how cool Tommy's is I just haven't returned and never will. That week and a half was just the absolute worst. With the loss of my work week, the doctor's visit and some necessary dry cleaning, the cons just outweigh the pro's for me on this one. If you go to Tommy's have a great time, just stay the heck away from the pickle barrel.

TZp9tzgSBV8C_plU4CvHAg.review_text: Very good overall. I like to come here whenever I'm in town, and want some comfort food. Thursdays and Sundays are my favorite days, as a braised lamb shank is on special those days. But the sandwiches, the stew, and the dinner plates are good, as well. Expect to wait in line, but service is pretty quick. While it might not be Swan Oyster Depot or House of Prime Rib, I've never been disappointed, and I always come back.

YaZL4JlzQRM4m4GQKCnNhQ.review_text: Pretty big plate with delicious all kinds of meat~

DOihVX5R0K1KFMaJm4ou_g.review_text: All I can say is 'meat, meat and more meat'...  If your craving a good hearty home made meal or comfort food, this is the place to go.   The food (namely meat) is awesome and they give you huge portions. The staff are really friendly and the place is super casual with a cafeteria style atmosphere.   The decor in this place is definitely one of a kind. There's so much going on in there, you'll never be bored. There were some little birds that looked way too real but when asked no one could tell me if they were real or fake - hmmmm.  All and all a great place if you're meat lover!

MXRTrew0VW3yvAgdIOJUow.review_text: What a treat!!!  SF can be an expensive city...check out this local "joynt" featured on Triple D's!!!  It's not to be missed!!!  Easy street parking was welcome after driving around the city all day.  Then!  The sign of a good establishment?  A line filled with locals...tons of businessmen on their lunch break and construction workers, and regulars who interact with the guys behind the counter like they are here everyday.  Loved it!    It's cafeteria style, and the guys behind the counter are extremely helpful.  Their daily specials looked great, but we stuck with what was featured on diners, drive-ins and dives.  Mom got the turkey dinner with house made gravy and practically licked her plate clean!!!  I had the roast beef dinner...get the sourdough roll--it's phenomenal!  Beef was tender and the au jus was a nice touch.  Generous portions at a great price.  Go.   Now.

-X5FV4fqOzvphOqG2vVglA.review_text: Tommy's Joint is a San Francisco institution! This is were the tourist rub elbows with the locals and Emperor Norton holds court. Great sports bar with just about everybeer from everywhere. Peggy is there to bring you a beer with a smile and a kind word.      A BIG plate of meat, potatoes and salad for about ten bucks!  Wonderful place for a date, dinner and movie (AMC movie theatre is across the street) without breaking the bank. Just remember to tip!

_BHTC7nyCBoZcfiiD5cOXg.review_text: It's to the Van Ness corridor what Lefty O'Doul's is to Union Square - a landmark in spite of itself.

EfLECHdYuO5z8RsPCzGaDA.review_text: Great prices! We had a pastrami dinner, lamb shank dinner and two desserts and it came to only $25.00!   The pastrami is spoon tender-dare I say too tender but delicious and the portion is huge!  The lamb shank is cooked like my mom cooked it-more like beef so if you're looking for a garlicky, rosemary, thymey lamb you won't get it here but if you're looking for a tender hunk of meat served with boiled potatoes, you'll get it here!  The desserts were good. I had the chocolate cake which was moist and not too chocolately and my partner in dine had the apple pie which was good, too.    This place has my favorite beer on tap-Crispin Cider beer! I've never seen it on tap before and unfortunately I didn't see it until after I was already drinking my Corona. :-(  Any way the food is good, you may have to add some salt and pepper, the portions are huge and the prices are awesome!  Would I come back?  Yep!

fgT7nACHhJ46mOhw7qe9qg.review_text: Food is good and the place has charm. Prices are decent and you will leave with a full stomach.  No overpriced, over hyped BS food goin on here.  Try the lamb chops or the meatloaf

Q7Qj6rTSIC6UVQ0a9xSyEQ.review_text: Went on Monday night for oxtail special.  Oxtails were great,but sauce was too sweet.  After Santa fe in reno it was disappointing

ENpIkmAhjfl1reW4EYyYkA.review_text: This is a place that is readily noticeable when you're driving along Van Ness, possibly looking for parking or something. Went here after fun times at the Real Escape Game that took place at the Regency a couple blocks away.  Cash-only place, with prices that don't make my wallet cry and food that is delicious and well worth the price. I don't eat too much meat, but ohhh man, that brisket was delicious. Nice place to chill and hang out over food comas from the enormous portions that you get. Yes. I will come back, mainly because I don't have to park since I'm close enough to walk, and it will be on one of those days where it's like, "Yeah, dude, I want to eat pretty much all the food right now." Nom nom stuffing. Next time I'm going to get turkey, which is what I actually wanted, but the boyfriend hates turkey so I opted for something we'd both enjoy.

H8d55Eh8HPYOdPDWJ2Dlsg.review_text: The food was alright. It was not the best beef dinner plate too. My plate was cold, it wasn't warm enough for me to enjoy. The service was lousy. My friend ordered the same plate but with mash potatoes, but the server poured gravy all over the plate without asking my friend if he wanted it or not (my friend hates gravy). Will I go back again? The answer is no!

QSFzDQTeLGQsV-YYJ8neuw.review_text: So cheap for how much food you get and it's good. Lots of options and good, old fashioned comfort food.

AcyysNzAxCMIKOv5swqL2w.review_text: I loved the atmosphere as well as the overly-decorated walls for it kept my eye busy while I was waiting in line.   Everyone was extremely friendly and the food was delicious. It almost felt like I was back home eating one of my Mom's home cooked meals... except it wasn't AS good  (the ham wasn't as juicy and flavorful).   The upstairs dining area was a bit more quiet and serene than the downstairs bar area, and it was just as nice. The service was great and so was the food! Also, fair prices for a dinner plate which includes a meat, mashed potatoes, baked beans or a salad!

ZhI2hV5S4PYkyI1BEQkRSQ.review_text: I dream about Tommy's Joynt. I lived next to Tommy's for 5 years and I miss it so bad now. Buffalo stew and BBQ beef, can have those all day. The drinks are cheap as well. Meat lovers paradise.

UUgjK995YbkyZ_t3O6APxQ.review_text: My father introduced me to this place about 5 years ago, and every time I'm in the City, I wind up coming here and ordering the Brisket, mashed potatoes, beans and one of my favorite beers (they have such a great selection).  There's no need to write a lengthy review.. Tommy's Joynt has the reputation as evidenced by the many positive reviews.

hPNvRl4jAXsYoBAAhudRrA.review_text: My long time culinary goal for the city of San Francisco was to find an authentic "San Franciscan" restaurant; a restaurant that encompasses all the unique flavors and elements of this great city, and serves food that its devourers can proudly proclaim it only available in this great city we live in.   Well, Tommy's Joynt is the exact opposite of that. The interior of this place makes you think the entire joynt is out of place in the golden gate city, and rather belongs somewhere in one of those industrial states like Michigan or Wisconsin; the place inundated with charming old-timey beer posters, possibly dating back from the Cold War or the Vietnam war era, reminiscent of one of those cafeteria-style restaurants you frequently see on the Travel Channel that Adam Richman often heralds as "meccas of comfort food." Tommy's serves comfort food that ubiquitous to every American city, state, region, you name it: barbecue sandwiches, brisket, mashed potatoes, collared greens, baked salmon... the list goes on. So sad to say, Tommy's Joynt wasn't exactly the "San Franciscan" restaurant I was looking for, but they meet every expectation of what comfort food should be.  As for the actual culinary experience itself, I got the "dinner set" with tender brisket and steamed green beans, accompanied by a side of macaroni salad and sour bread. The brisket simply melts in your mouth and the steamed green beans crumble with every chew--I would even venture to say all the food here is "just how my grandma made it" if not for the fact that my grandma spent most of her younger years in Japanese-occupied Korea, and that she hated (god rest her soul) American food with a flaring passion.
