Or do you do it?  Go for broke, jump in a jalopy and head to Tommy's Joynt for 2 more hours of beer and food and bullshit with friends!  Tomorrow you'll wake up feeling like shit, with just 3 hours of sleep, bleary eyed through your morning and there's nothing coffee or water or magic kombucha can do to make you forget that last night you were the King of SF.  Also, they serve beer and alcohol at Tommy's

KW8X0qUW9p8lInOVOgL1zA.review_text: Not the greatest sandwich  - I asked about the turkey bar-b-que and the server said it was great... but after he added turkey gravy to the bar-b-que sandwich - well...

8hvXl0oJmU61l17LG9aDag.review_text: the first time i came to tommys, i think it was 1992. i was a sophmore in high school and wanted something different than the usual burger king or taco bell after school so i came by here. i tried my hardest to convince the guy behind the bar i was 21, but he wasnt having any of it. i got a plate of food from some dude with a mustache and chefs hat.   fast foward a few more years, oh shit, that dude with the mustache still works here. crazy.  fast forward a few more years, oh shit, that mustache guys still works here.   repeat   repeat.   this weekend. oh shit that mustache guy still works here! crazy.   the food is just as good as i remembered. nothing fancy, just meat and some other stuff.   the beer of the world list has shrunk a bit, but for the better.   the thing i noticed the most that changed was the size of the girls titties on the mural outside. i swear they were bigger when i was younger.   come here for surprisingly good meat plates, turkey wings, brisket, corned beef.... come here for the divey diner feel. come here to drink beers with your boys.....  and another funny thing.... everyone can relate.... some people when they have a sit down, they leave their pants at about mid thigh.. some drop it like its hot all the way down to the ground. its funny walking into a bathroom and seeing someones pants and belt on the floor in a stall... this visit. i opened the door and saw a radio, a flashlight, a GUN!?!??! i take a step in and just like we turn down our phones when in the stall, one of sf finests turned down his radio when the chatter came on. HA. funny scene.

SVtNctg9k2QOGj0znfHVwQ.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is the perfect spot for your booze break.    Scenario: it's midnight on a friday, you hit up happy hour after work and you decided you needed more happy so you've been bar hopping until now. You've only eaten light munchies so you really feel like demolishing something substantial. Tommy's Joynt is the solution.   From the moment you walk in all you can think is "I want to eat everything I can smell!" The delicious aroma of cooked meats is just overpowering, and even if you didn't know you were hungry you now have no choice!   I went with the french dip sandwich...I'm not even sure if this is on the menu, but I ordered it and they made it. The roast beef was perfectly cooked. Still as red as it should have been. The bread was amazing too. And the dip was the perfect flavor. I also got mac & cheese and coleslaw on the side. Glad I was sharing this because I probably could have finished it all...but would have hated myself for it afterwards.   The rest of your night may be a blur....but you won't forget the amazing and perfectly timed meal you had at Tommy's Joynt!

cVpgMH3CMHDcUcIzjy9NBQ.review_text: Was in SF for Christmas/New Year, and had to try this place.  I saw it on Food Network, and it looked like a dump (read: "classic").  Tommy's Joynt is at the corner of two very busy streets in downtown.  Parking was pretty easy to find a block away.  From the look of it outside and in, it reminded me of a few places in LA.  I liked the old time charm and grit, and the bar looked very inviting.  Unfortunately the food did not live up to my expectations.  I saw the big cuts of meat out and absolutely had to try one of their famous big sandwiches.  I opted for the roast beef.  I saw them pull out a big roll and thought "Wow, I'll never finish that!".  Turns out it's just a big roll they cut into little pieces.  It was maybe 8in what I got.  Surely they'll pile on the meat though... nope, a standard amount of meat.  I liked the au jus that was served with the sandwich, but that was the only good part of it.  The meat was otherwise bland and flavorless.  I also heard good things about the buffalo chili, but what I got tasted like a standard canned beef chili.  My gf wanted to try the lamb shank special.  It was unevenly cooked so that some parts were really good with the gravy and all, but other parts were tough.  One of my friends got the pastrami sandwich, which she said was dry (even with the juice).  She didn't even finish it, a sure sign that it's not irresistable.  We also had a vegetarian in our group, and all they had for him was a swiss cheese sandwich.  Really?  How many years has it been open, and they never figured out some vegetarian options?!  There are also a few people saying this place is cheap.  Compared to a steakhouse, yes. $6 for the sandwich + $3 for the cup of chili does not equal cheap to me.  I had better eats in SF for a lot cheaper, and those included leftovers.  This place left me hungry, but not for their food.  Maybe you'll like it if you were raised on it, and maybe some out-of-towners might enjoy.  This Angelino will take the sandwiches of Phillipe's and Cole's PE Buffet any day, and actually leave satisfied.

R02RyZDUITwDsvmz5nm1Hw.review_text: I only had 30 min for lunch and when I saw 8 people in line I was a little nervous, but then it was my turn just as I was deciding what I wanted. An amazing fresh sliced pastrami on great source dough roll.

L9G2g7UQtd3YGxnSjKTUrQ.review_text: A sandwich is hard to mess up. Get the right meat and bread and it's great. The brisket sandwich just wasn't all it's hyped up to be. The meat, although tasty, was too fatty. The bread didn't seem too fresh. The best part was the BBQ sauce which seemed homemade.  The place had a weird vibe. Divey but not that welcoming for some reason (it's really dark and kinda depressing).  Overall it was a bit better than ok.

UHeWcZyue4By6F8CfMaPHg.review_text: history, eclectic, and fun... the atmosphere   Bang up great bistro food. fresh hot meats served to order, corned beef, pastrami, roast beef and turkey, gravy sandwiches and dinner style, and the daily specials you can count on   all home made salads, fresh and yummy, beet, cucumber, potato whatever alllll grrreattt!   full bar, good people, homey, sports on TV, late night if ya need to, lunch, fast but not fast food.... I recommend it all. Enjoy!  I put two $$ for the fact there is a bar and a drink/beer could put you over the 11.00 mark ... if with a friend split a side/salad or two to get more flavor for your buck

uJ75W39QMMNNP6idCviLWA.review_text: Found this place through friends we went shooting with one evening (cameras, not guns).   I've driven by a few dozen times but just thought it was a bar. In a sense though, it sorta is with the massive beer selection they've got! too bad I can't have any. Alas.  Simply, LOVED IT! Gluttonous food and very reasonable prices for the area. You should go. Like, right now.

PxpcMrKgjcRk6qQz83wJYg.review_text: If you were super drunk after a punk rock show in 1980s or early 90s this was the place to eat. The funny thing is its still the same in every way. It is old school U.S. cafeteria style haufbrau. When I was a young punk alcoholic I loved the food and the prices. In 1993 I brought my visiting German friends from the psychobilly band Mad SIn to eat here. They hated it! If drunk Germans do not like your German food then you know your in trouble. Basically, this is 1950s American food disguised as Haufbrau. Its only good for broke punks, cheap rich people, and grandparents. If you want quality  Haufbrau go to Suppenküche in Hayes Valley--lots of horrible yuppies but good authentic German food.

63SQPROZ48xwGUb2LloFQA.review_text: I love Tommy's Joynt for the novelty of it all, but when I eat there it's only because I've been drinking very nearby, and am not in a position to get a proper late night snack i.e. Burrito or Thai noodles.  Still, you gotta love the selection of international beers and the soup kitchen feel of the place. When I go there I feel like my dad must have 45 years ago when he first moved to SF and couldn't speak English.  Giblets anyone?

6y3eGjvAHxaK-IPuxFbz8Q.review_text: I had just arrived in SF and got to my hotel, The Opal, across the street. My room wasn't quite ready, but I was starving. I heard good things about Tommy's, so I had to go check it out. I am so glad I found this great little spot. I ordered the brisket and mashed potatoes. While I am a smoked brisket fanatic, I do have to say that the brisket here was cooked to perfection. Very good home cooked meals. The prices were reasonable and the portions were generous.   Added bonus: As I sat down at the bar, I noticed that Chris Robinson, the lead singer of the Black Crowes and Chris Robinson Brotherhood, was sitting right to my left. Stoked!

A4MLgWcMaUsWuE9HdQj-0A.review_text: huge Turkey leg for under $8 with a salad and roll... I dare you to find a better deal. The place definitely has character and some may call it a tourist trap but a lot of locals go here... I come when I'm really hungry for greasy meaty comfort food... They have really good salads too that change regularly. Cash only! they do have an ATM though

Cp4JiQA_eW0O-JctBljdPQ.review_text: I like the idea of Tommy's Joynt more than I like the actual experience of eating there.  There is indeed something charmingly retro about this hofbrau-style eatery and its cluttered decor.  And if that isn't enough, it just reeks of SF history.    I am the first to appreciate a cheap meal, but the quality of the food here just ain't up to snuff.  The meats are way fatty and lack flavor.  The turkey is dry and flavorless.  The gravy is totally starchy and bland.  Veggies are canned and gross beyond explanation.  Salad is iceberg lettuce and a ton of dressing.  Perhaps it is nervy of me to expect more.  At Tommy's, you get what you pay for.  Silver Lining: The bar does have an excellent beer selection if you are craving a harder to find foreign brew.  Tommy's probably deserves more like two stars, but the charm of the place earned it its third.  And hey, what are your other options in this hood, Mel's?

6XCZoufB_S-sY6vsxMGd8Q.review_text: I am going to offend a lot of people by giving this place a 2 star review. I know.........it was on diners, drive ins, and dives. I know......it's been here for like 1000 years. I know a lot of people grew up eating here. Let's put that aside and concentrate on the food.   The food itself is your cafeteria style format............sorta like chick and coop on Taraval. I personally don't like that place neither. Maybe I am just not a Hauf brau kinda guy. I also should have known when my friend picked this restaurant. If you are ever looking for all of the best 2 star restaurants in the city, let me know and I'll introduce you to him.   I ordered the meatball sandwich. The meatballs were luke warm to borderline cold. The meat sauce helped bring the temperature up a level but it was still, at best, warm. The establishment itself is in a bar, a dive bar. The price is reasonable and the seating area is scattered but this place can hold a lot of people. My other friend who ordered the spaghetti and meatballs agreed with me. I would not bring out of towners here, unless you don't like them or you don't want them to come back and visit you. This is probably a place I would eat if I had no other choice and if I was stuck on the corner of Van Ness and Geary. I would even choice Mel's across the street. Gosh.........I hate that place too. hahahhhaa.   Patrons who eat here are your typical middle class to blue collar workers and mostly tourists. A lot of my friends actually come here late at night after a night of boozing. Probably one of the reasons why they like this place that much.

VKybeTwTgn-F6cuh5ArVIQ.review_text: first dinner in sf was at tommys joint, just a couple blocks down from where we were staying.   the place looks like a well-established joint with a bar on one side, and food service on the other. it is cash only and you order like a cafeteria and pay at the end.   4 of us shared 3 dinner plates (we each had clam chowder bread bowls an hour prior to dinner)  we had bbq brisket with mashed potatoes and cole slaw, corned beef with mashed potatoes and beans, and sweet and sour spare ribs with rice.  potatoes and beans and coleslaw were pretty good. bbq brisket was our favorite corned beef was a bit too salty for us and the spare ribs were ok, but there were some tough, stringy, dried out parts. nice flavor though.  grab your own pickles and water and silverware. grab a seat and grub. simple, fast, good, cheap.

NCAO2KuKuOeMUM7kvXl7Fw.review_text: These guys know wtf they're doin when it comes to sandwiches... I'm not even a huge pastrami fan.. until I tried Tommy's pastrami... fuckin kill.. absolutely insane..

B-7QSsJYW90NFjmZbyKL_A.review_text: So yummy! So cheap! So juicy and fat! I ate some of the barbeque beef, which was fresh, hot, and so tasty. Paired with some mashed potatoes with chunky gravy (and my personal addition of Tapatio!), it was a meaty, creamy, fatty taste of heaven.   I recommend not having a drink here the first time you go, because you want that extra room in your belly for food! But if I lived closer to this place, it could easily become "that spot" for hanging with friends and having a good time. Because it's got everything you need for being your spot--cheap yet delicious food, incredible drink selection, and a friendly and comfortable atmosphere.  I give Tommy's Joynt five stars, and then some! See Andrew N.'s review for more info!   PS: Andrew was all over the spicy mustard. Give it a taste, if you dare!!!

j4eqBy3a-5bQdQ-Nd8FUvA.review_text: I guess we all have different tastes when it comes to food. Expected more from this place coz it seemed popular. Brisket was soooooooo fatty. Corned beef sandwich? The corned beef was a lil tough. I would rather buy those corned beef brisket packs at Harris ranch, its more tastier. At least I have tried the place!

y4ULuS_wBCj1K8dT8IiRDw.review_text: When people come here, they shouldn't expect the highest quality food or five star service. The people who work here are almost like family, they give you choose and are friendly enough. After all this place is a Hofbrau (German for an informal restaurant or tavern) a cafeteria-style restaurant. You come here for the experience of a kooky decorated place and some classic American food. It's close to AMC Van Ness, so you can catch a movie before or after Tommy's Joynt!   Food:  * Turkey - good, but in general craved turkey doesn't have much flavor them anyways  * Corned Beef - good  * Pastrami - good  * Veggie sides - a little over cooked to my liking  * Desserts - they're OK  * Salad - fresh and crisp   Drinks:  * Beers  * Well drinks  * Soda   Service:  * Nice sold folks!   I'd say go check this class San Francisco Joynt, better than Mel's cross the street ;D!

NYuBM_p8xWQETivVDWNBTg.review_text: $4.50 Martini on the rocks. Who knew? My pre-AMC Van Ness treat.  I love the Buffalo Stew with Pork and Beans and Rice.  Hot homestyle food served fresh!

8_e7-Eu98mTep1T0kTHrIQ.review_text: Can u say amazing food, thats all i gotta say!!!!

_SVAW_bwFx3G2tDqmsmOBw.review_text: Meat and Potatoes is what this place should be renamed.  Or maybe Meat N' Carbs because they're all here; bread, potatoes, rice, potato salad, etc.  Luckily Tommy's does the meat part very well.  Trying both the pastrami and beef round, the meat was very flavorful and juicy.  It comes piled in a decent amount on a sandwich of your choosing which is great.  Unfortunately I didn't find too much diversity in the menu.  Again, meat and carbs and I didn't find either in proportion enough to justify the price.  I know the sandwiches come in under $6 but given that they are literally just meat and bread (old world sandwich?), I found it a bit lacking.  I thought charging $2.50 for the salad was a bit laughable.  The beverage scene was ok but not amazing.  They have Chimay white on draft but nothing else is really original or appealing.  Trumer can definitely help wash down some of beef.    In either case, be warned this isn't a place you come for healthy food and if you're looking to put down some food, be ready to shell out some cash.  What they offer isn't exactly bad, I think I just wasn't sure what to expect from this place.

d5C23GmGk0ZDyjTPyjl3mA.review_text: Been coming here for years.  When I am in SF, I make it a point to eat here.  Each and every time, it has been very good.  Great roast beef/mashed potatoes!

3W8a5Fp6s2Bw8O71ckgqpA.review_text: I've always known this place to exist whenever I drove by it on Van Ness street...but going inside for the first time late last night was indeed a pleasant surprise.  When my friends recommended Tommy's Joynt for a late evening dinner after a 5-hr photography lesson, I didn't have very high expectations.  I figured as long as it was edible food, I'd be ok with it since SF doesn't typically offer many dining options in the wee hours of the night.    Little did I know that for $10.04, I could get a big portion of beef brisket with a side of veggies, a cucumber salad & bread.  Although it was no Gary Danko's... the food quality was very impressive.  The brisket was soft and flavorful.  The "veggies' were actually just string beans...but it still complimented the brisket well.  The side of cucumber salad was fresh and crunchy and had just the right amount of tang to it.  As for the sourdough bread.... it was great dipping that into the brisket au jus.  Yummy yum yum!  All in all, I will have to say that I will never judge a restaurant by it's outside appearance ever again.  Sometimes the treasures found inside can be a wonderful surprise!

X4esoUAQtbvh-UkyHkDSlg.review_text: I love this place... large variety of beers.. good sandwiches, my favorite bbq beef always tender and juice.. sides are pretty good hahah.. great prices too.. what else could you ask for..

qJGSfhwook3gqJbSTBhirg.review_text: Turns out this place is kind of like a cafeteria style restaurant. The crew behind the counter, as well as the folks working the floor, was very nice, friendly and helpful. You stand in line for food but once you sit down there is table service for your drinks. The beer selection is great.  They have daily specials & lots of meat dishes.  Food: The roast beef was dry, but the turkey leg was pretty spot on and really helped my boyfriend get that late night grub on.  Drinks: Impressive collection of beers.  Prices: not low, but decent.

bV4m22UFyuNYC8vvQUgFwA.review_text: I've always passed this place when I'm near Geary and Van Ness, but never knew how awesome this place was until I was hungry after a softball game @ 10pm.  First of all, it's pretty awesome that they are open until 2am.  Second, this place is very MEATY and you get the bang for your bunk for $6-$10 meals.  Their gravy sweet bean side dish is really good and best bean side dish I've had (looks orange).  It pairs really well with the pork shoulder.  I also ordered a turkey leg just because I kept seeing pictures of it on Yelp.  Although the outside part of the leg tasted a little dry, it was still a decent dish because it was ALL DARK MEAT.    Yummmmm!  They have a hof brau like family style table settings that you can sit down and eat at if you plan on dining in and the side of the bar looks very "divey".    FYI--this place is CASH ONLY!

z-7jJYZJLlKUerNg-kvgLQ.review_text: Tommy's is the best. Great home cooked food. I can order just about anything off the menu and be totally happy.

cbp8bmaRw_m5GwkEWDmOCA.review_text: First time I tried Buffalo!!!!   Quite tasty.....we were on the tour bus ,saw  the place and hopped on.....all because of Guy Fieri !!!   Love that show! Dining area was kinda dark, but enjoyed our meal which was very filling!! I think we walked it off going back to Powell Street....we had fun in SF!!!   Can't wait for trip # 3....date of visit  10/2010

Zpdh9rHGEHkwJwrsTbHnyA.review_text: Tommy's Joynt Haiku   "sticks to your ribs" joynt is what Tommy's all about  And volumes of beer  A wall of foreign Chimay on tap, read the walls Barrel of pickles  Cheap, 8 dollar plates Corned beef, brisket, sausages Hearty German fare   Quite eccentric crowd Young, old, rich, poor - all hungry  Open late - till 2!

NKIt0nhcs8x6yDRNdayDhA.review_text: One of the best corned beef sandwiches this side of the Mississippi.  I had heard such great things about this place - that it was a SF institution, and that it had the best sandwiches, beef, and stew in the city. So when I was in the neighborhood and hungry for lunch, I knew I had to stop by and check it out.    The corned beef really rocked my world.  It's such a simple sandwich, but it's so delicious, and the meat itself it really incomparable.  You walk up to the counter and order, and the man behind the glass stabs a hunk of meat, slices up some juicy cuts, and slaps them on a fresh sourdough bun so fast, he'll have your head spinning!   It was so simple, in fact, that after watching him make it, I doubted how good it was going to be.  Silly me. The meat was so tender and the au jus so savory; the bread was the perfect balance of crunchy and soft that it didn't upstage the meat - it managed to work with it.  The whole sandwich was really a perfect combination of flavors and textures.  I devoured it.  (It helped that I spent a whole morning working up an appetite walking around the city. This lunch was like my sweet reward.)  On thing to note that was good, but less than perfect: the brussels sprouts. They were fine. Not necessarily what I was expecting, but fine nonetheless.  I was expecting them to be hot, and roasted with butter...but when I popped the first one in my mouth, I was surprised to discover that it was cold and marinated in a generic vinaigrette.  Something I would expect from a Vegas all-you-can-eat buffet.  The baked beans, however, which we also tried, was a more satisfactory side dish.

cI5puqZckvEnpFGpwDOcKQ.review_text: Don't just go here if you saw it on an episode of Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives.  Do go here if you want a very tasty roast beef sandwich or a yummy turkey leg or even if you just want a plain old turkey sandwich on a french roll, all at a very reasonable price.  If you get the turkey dinner platter, the mashed potatoes and stuffing are forgettable.  My wife did not really like the sides that much.  But the turkey is fresh and yummy.  And the place is a classic.  A throwback to the old days.  My son and I both agreed as soon as we left the other day -  that we couldn't wait to come back and try the beef brisket and the corned beef.  So many things to eat.  So little time.  By the way - no long lines if you go there in the mid-afternoon.

2w03TT-I-6qXA4hm3O1Q_w.review_text: I dont care if Metallica eats here all the time.   I saw a few cockroaches and left quickly. Lars is a d**k

FhwFVj0kcvyRFK2pZaKdkA.review_text: This joint was recommended by a bartender as a must visit in San Fran. We have never eaten such crap food so fast in our lives. The people were rude, the water was grey, the facilities were trashy. This was the only "old school" eatery in San Fran where it want even worth the $20. Don't Do It!

3S53VaMDPy8Lywk2TuPb4A.review_text: We went for Thanksgiving lunch. We had a great time. There was a big lineup but we went in expecting that. Everyone was friendly and in a festive mood.  The time passed quickly. We ordered the full on turkey dinner with extra sides of beans and sweet potatoes. It came with turkey, dressing, mashed potatoes, gravy, roll, and pumpkin pie. It was all tasty.  My only real complaint was that the food was not really hot. It was kind of luke warm. But I still enjoyed it.  Tommy's Joynt is a great throwback. It's a classic. I had not been there in years. I am glad I returned.

IOu8iwTvspwCAMHFx9ai9Q.review_text: Great spot! The girlfriend and I try to hit this place every couple of weeks for the BBQ sandwich and to catch the Giants game. Be careful with the hot mustard! its potent! I learned the hard way.

7xE1tBIzMAkVbcms1GfloQ.review_text: A true blue-collar San Francisco bar with an eclectic twist, where anyone, no matter how rich or poor, feels at home. This is hands-down the best place to go after a long week at work. Cheap but good strong drinks, and cheap but amazing filling food. Anything from a gin&tonic with steamed salmon, to a Russian stout with a roasted leg of lamb. Or maybe you want a massive corned beef sandwich on sourdough with a house margarita? Whatever floats your boat - you've got it! I will not hesitate to say that this is hands-down the cheapest and best place to get food and drink in the city. Don't forget though, it's cash only, luckily an ATM awaits you inside.

udjIUpEIygQXgypWmnIeHg.review_text: I came back here with friends before our concert at The Regency Ballroom, conveniently located a few blocks away.   It was packed to the gills with tourists, young locals, and parents with kids out for a family-style dinner.  After much hemming and hawing, I decided upon the Roast Beef Sandwich.  I'm adding a star for this moist and delicious sandwich!  Make sure you have them dip your sourdough bread, and grab yourself some free sliced pickles on the side. They make all the difference : )

EkEhaWgCm_7l-OA8dsnfSQ.review_text: I love watching DD&D to see which places I should give a go at.  Tommy's Joynt is a place that I would go to over and over again because of the food.  It is simple and delicious, plus it's so cheap and they give you a really good amount of food.  The first time I had the turkey enchilada, sooo good!  The sauce was delicious and very unique...it was not too thin, but also not thick.  Perfect consistency pretty much and it was super tasty.  The second time I went I got the knockwurst sandwich, and it too was good.  However, it was too much bread for not that much meat (since the knockwurst is not too wide).  The food is authentic and you can see everything before you order something so it kind of makes ordering easier.  I love the fact that they have free pickles that are self serve because I love pickles!  The only down side to this place is that parking can be hard to find and they are cash only.  If someone didn't know that and they didn't have any cash then it probably would be a pain.  Other than those two things, it is such a great find.

Gpidr1_u1NSgZ2pm--KHAw.review_text: Wow! Where do I begin with this place. I've been coming here for years but had to stop due to some inappropriate comments made by the manager (female lady) to one of my relatives I was dining with who is part of the LGBT community. It was unbelievable. Not only because it was wrong but we are in the heart of San Francisco. HELLO!!  For that reason alone I stopped coming for a few years. I decided to try it once again. I sat at the bar ordered a few drinks. Same bartender as years before. Nice guy. They no longer have fat tire on tap. Darn! I ventured over to the cafeteria style line and ordered the roast beef meal. It was a 3 out of 5. Nothing special but not bad.  The stairs to the bathroom are windy and narrow so heads up if you are on crutches or have a disability.   All in all it was ok but nothing to go out of your way for.

rKhZlF7W7YZT7gUSKHY5NA.review_text: What a lovely date night. Superbad followed by Tommy's Joynt. What could be more romantic than staring into each others eyes over mounds of mashed potatoes, bbq beef, baked beans, and coleslaw? Wash that down with some Chimay and a Hefe and you are good to go.  But seriously, I really like Tommy's Joynt. The bbq turkey Sloppy Joe is off the chain as are their mashed potatoes and gravy. And they have a barrel full of pickles. I love a good Hofbrau, I am not a hard girl to please...

WMEN3Tgb5TjhGw7xa_NEQw.review_text: I hadn't been here for a while. The first time was in college years ago. It hasn't changed a lick since then. Well, the sausage sandwich is $3.25 instead of 89 cents. But for whatever reason, I love this place! The food is nothing special, and there's a fine beer menu. But the ambience! This place, with it's cluttered walls and ceilings, drinking memorabilia, the checkered tablecloths and steam table, is really something else. You want old San Francisco, here it is. Really worth a  visit.

qGRcdYwshheRwU7wKS2n4w.review_text: Great stuff.  Went with 3 adults and one 3-year old and all left full and happy.  The meats are excellent - we had ham, roast beef, and pastrami - all were delicious.  Simple but really good food.  And the place has a lot of character.  Will be going back for sure.

2JpUDC466JCAiRMuXFhnHA.review_text: All the makings of a fav food spot....  cheap fresh delicious  Once you get there, take a moment to soak in the atmosphere...Tommy's is a unique place with a lot of charm.  Great location right at the corner of Geary and Van Ness.    Fresh pastrami sandwiches for the late nighters...for under $6....love it. The meat from the pastrami is super juicy and tender.

liyp1KxjFBhx2ENgF_sY8g.review_text: great food, bad service, rude staff  ive been to this establishment many times in the past the food has always been awsome they need to work on there tact.

em8v20UxN9kc7f41ERNedg.review_text: Tommy's is an excellent place to get a hearty meal and a few drinks on a cold rainy day, and that's exactly what I did.  I tried to have brunch at Red Door Cafe, but since it has seating for 4 people in total, they were obviously booked.  It was raining so I decided that we should try to find somewhere to eat quickly.  Having passed by this place many times, I still didn't quite know what to expect, but it looked interesting to say the least.  Stepping inside is like stepping back in time.  It seems that they started decorating in the 40's when they opened and have never bothered to take anything down.. they just keep adding stuff.  Remarkably, this makes for a very welcoming environment.  There are lots of large communal tables in the main room, and booths in back.  The food was decent.  We're not talking gourmet SF style, but if you're looking for the sticks to your ribs kind of food that warms the soul on a cold day, then this is the place.  It's hoffbrau style, kind of like a served buffet.  I got the buffalo stew, which was pretty good.  I also enjoyed an irish coffee to round out my cold weather brunch.  The irish coffee was pretty good, again, it's not the buena vista, but it would be worth coming back for.  All in all, check out Tommy's, you won't be sorry.

v1YDRJOSSg0whV4nnMSUdA.review_text: This place is pretty good for its price. I got the brisket dinner plate which I really enjoyed. Mash potatoes were good, coleslaw was alright, and the beans sucked.   Good for groups, place is actually huge. Crowded in the front though when it hits prime time. Friendly environment, I would definitely go back here to try different things.

A_VjRVBktoaxTiBZKW_48g.review_text: As they say on the radio, "Long time listener, first time caller."  As a seriously addicted yet very silent follower of Yelp I decided that my first review should be for a place that I love.  Which brings me to Tommy's Joynt.  That weird building on the corner of Van Ness and Geary that you have passed by millions of times but never built up enough courage to actually walk in the swinging doors.  But aren't you just a little curious?  Sure you can smell it from across the street (a smell that I haven't decided is good or not) and sure its a little intimdating...but Beers of the world?  Meat carved to order?  There are more reasons to check it out than to pass it by.    I will admit, I was like you.  I have a somewhat clear memory of my friends and I wandering Van Ness (slightly intoxicated) looking for somewhere to eat (that wasn't Mel's Drive In) when one of us suggested trying Tommys, we walked in, we looked around, we read the menu, and my vegetarian friend said, "No way in hell" and we walked out.  This was my first experience with the infamous Joynt.    It wasn't for probably another year that I finally got the chance to try Tommys.  It was St Patricks Day, corned beef and cabbage was necessary, irish carbombs flowed like water, it was packed, cheap, and delicious!  It wasn't long after that that my roommate and I became regulars.  We would sit at the bar chat it up with the bartender Jose and take shots of tequilla (i know, wrong tommys to do that in) but it was our thing, shots of tequilla and pints of beer one after the other after the other until we were drunk and hungry then we'd get in line, grab a booth, and eat!    Between the two of us we've had alot!  We've had the corned beef sandwiches, the pastrami, the turkey, the bbq'd beef, the other beef, the buffalo stew, the spaghetti, the lamb shank each one good enough to have again and again!  The help yourself pickle barrel (filled with homemade pickles) is the reason why I eat pickles.  The sides are also good, potato salad, macaroni salad, green beans straight from a can (ok, sometimes you just need a veggie, even if it isn't really that healthy).  I am pretty sure I had a love affair with Tommys.  C'mon Irish coffees, nutty irishmen and PINA COLADAS that they make with this tiny blender and without a mix, whats not to love?  Okay, sure it isn't as nice when they don't have room at the bar or in one of those 4 very cool booths.  And yes it smells funny.  And it doesn't appear that clean and yes it totally sucks to have to walk up those steep narrow steps after 5 shots of tequilla to use the bathroom...but its been there for YEARS!  And the people are nice.  The bartenders are totally old school (Jose's family makes tequilla somewhere in Mexico, he'll show you pics of agave plants if you ask!).  And where else can you go and find a busser with Mario's mustache?  Because he works there!  AND I'm pretty sure John Voigt is a regular (he drinks the cheap cheap wine that they serve in margarita type glasses)..okay its not really him, but it sure looks like him and he really is there every single time that I am.    What I'm trying to say is Tommy's is good, its classic, its cheap, they serve food till 1:30 am or something like that, they have good strong drinks and every lover of food in San Francisco should try it...at least once, but leave your vegetarian friend at home!

ZRWnelu3sxHHONvDc0xtaw.review_text: a large variety of food served cafeteria style, with ample seating around  The beef brisket is the best thing on their menu, and I'm not usually a beef person! Insider tip from a wise friend: the bbq sauce is sweet and tangy - get the bbq sauce on your mashed potatoes too instead of the normal gravy!  Despite the hype, I actually wasn't a fan of the turkey sloppy joe or the buffalo stew. Stuffing was a pretty good side dish though.

mvjuaMGOeBSLqZO53ORSrw.review_text: So I watched an episode of Diners drive-ins and dives about a week before going here and my mouth was watering from watching Guy eat the tender brisket and I told myself if i ever go to San Fran again I will go here. And as it turned out I was surprised with a trip to San Fran a week later and of course remembered this place! When I got in I could smell all of the meats and new I would be in for an amazing meal.  I got the brisket plate with mashed potatoes and coleslaw. AMAZING! And all included in the price! The bbq gravy they put over everything was to die for as well! The brisket was so tender and there was tons of it!  It was so good I have cravings for it all the time and unfortunately live 8 hours away. Hopefully I will be returning soon! LOVE THIS PLACE!

yG906x3lEDRBy_egNLcy4Q.review_text: Food was of low quality, ordered the beef brisket which had little to no flavor and too much fat. I Also ordered the salad with Italian dressing which turned out to be pure vinegar and too tart to eat.   They no longer serve buffalo burgers which they were previously famous for, instead there was buffalo stew and buffalo chili. Sever at the meat counter was impatient when asked about the burgers he didn't want to explain the other options, stew was way too salty. We were asked how the food was and we explained about the salad to which the reply was, "Do you want to add ranch on it?" How was that going to make a salad drenched in vinegar better? There was no reply. This has turned into more of a generic Hoff Braugh  restaurant.

Lu8y2ayxVlAzuJEVfVcH4w.review_text: I LOVE Tommy's Joynt, it reminds me of when I was young when my parents and grandparents took me here to get that good old fashioned cooking. It's classic and brings back great memories every time.   My favorite is the Corned Beef and Cabbage they offer on a weekly basis. They have fresh corned beef everyday, but only Corned Beef and Cabbage once a week. I also come here on St. Patrick's Day and wait in line, because I love it so much it's worth the wait.  One of the Managers once told me that if they changed once of the daily specials, they would get multiple complaints - so it stays the same. Original and Local Flavor at it's best.  I love the cucumber salad, mashed potatoes and gravy, bean salad - these are the "blue plate" special type sides that my family loved. I love the big barrel of pickles, which is self serve and free.  Tommy's is truly a part of San Francisco History.

A6-tpXToVbhCKk7BxLMZNQ.review_text: Growing up I always saw this place when I would take the 38 Geary to go to the dentist or doctor. Fast forward years later even after I turned 18 I still just saw the sign outside always curious what it was like in there.  When I finally went in to eat I was fascinated by the decorations and even more the menu of alcohol and the food looking absolutely mouth watering on the serving/carving tables. After the first bite of my beef brisket I knew that I had to come back to try all the other items!  After several meals here I don't think I have had a bad experience other than the carver in the beginning having bad attitudes but they warm up to you after awhile.   OK so here are my favorites ....  Turkey with rice, stuffing, and gravy! Side spaghetti (with some really bomb sauce) - A MUST Salmon special (I believe on Fridays) Beef Stew Clam Chowder BBQ Beef or Roast Beef with Mashed Potatoes or Rice and sauce  The best part is that you can leave this place FULL for less than $10.

Hl4FVghtpqUhh5S90JmPxw.review_text: Love this place! They have all kinds of food and it's not too expensive. We seen this place two years ago on Diners, dives and drive-ins! and always talked about going.. We finally made it over here... Can I just say AWESOME! I loved everything about this place.. First they had my favorite Thanksgiving dinner.. Mash potatoes, turkey and gravy all over with stuffing. So wonderful the mashers were tasty and the turkey was juicy. They are not shy either they pile it on your plate. My husband got the rib special, they were huge and he ate every bit of food on his plate and so did I. We can't forget to talk about the awesome variety of drinks from all around the world.. There are so many we didn't know what to order, I ended up with a Shiner Bock and he got a Red Stripe, they have choices from everywhere and we had these drinks.. Too funny. We also, ordered bloody mary's you have a choice of whatever Vodka you want in it and if you want it spicy or real spicy. So good! The place is decorated with every old beer tin ever made, old pictures and vintage everything including the lighting. The only thing that sucked was we had to keep running out to the street to put more change in the meter. I guess they have underground parking but we couldn't find it.. However, no worries the waitresses are super friendly and were happy to change our dollar bills, remember that if you run out of change. We for sure will be back again. If you are in the city you have, have, have to eat lunch or dinner here.

1fgqYpHnp4rJFv5LcQGMQQ.review_text: When you're done with the superfluous foodie crap food sporting an equally a superfluous bill and you're looking for something to really hit the spot like one of those meals at your grandmothers house after a long day of driving to get there.... yes, yes this sounds good. You've found it: Tommy's Joynt   Come on in and immediately a savory slow cooked meal awaits. The quality isn't epic. You won't jizz your pants orgasming over the complex layered flavors designed into the food. Buy you'll get a good meal at a fair price, and that's saying quite a bit these days. The ordering is cafeteria style but the food isn't. You can eat at a table or belly on up to the bar if that's your style.   I had the beef round sandwich, good and hearty with great flavor when liberally smothered with the accompanying au jus sauce. I also had a 2 olive kettle one martini, up, which was OK but heavy on the vermouth I think.   I will most certainly be coming back when in the mood.  Nice staff and a timeless atmosphere.

jCeQiA7pndcGm3TmTG4F1w.review_text: I know I like it here because all of my memories from here are blurry.  P.s. the bartender from Guatemala is awesome!  Edit: 1. Crappy and minimal food options if you do not eat meat. This is a highly-vegetarian city. 2. Cash only. But, cash really helps monitor drunk drink buying?  !!!!!!!!!!!FREE PICKLES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! :D

zRg160atYRF8qjTdBBa-SQ.review_text: I would give this place 4.5 stars. I am a proud meat eater, so I definitely enjoyed their amazingly juicy meat options. The atmosphere is quite fun and feels a bit homey, like it's not some packed restaurant in a big city. I definitely would recommend this place to people.

nc8FNauv1981OY4WkqsvFg.review_text: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.    The buffalo chili is the best chili that I have ever had, and I have tried alot of chili.  They serve the chili over a white rice, I ask for more chili and less rice because if you dont they will make it about 50/50 portion.  There are no huge chunks of buffalo but thats the way I like it.  It isnt a particularly dark or light chili, its right in the middle.  Certainly not soupy, but not over thick either.  It comes with a small sourdough roll and butter but I usually ask for one extra.  Then I scoop the chili and rice onto the roll and use the roll as a spoon that I can bite into.   I get a side of salad with the Italian house dressing.  It is really bitter and tangy but in an awesome way.    Tons of beers from all over the world but I usually get a pitcher of Anchor Steam or sometimes Heineken.  Its the only time I ever drink Heineken but it seems to just go with the chili and salad for some reason.  The only time I dont get the chili is when they are serving the lasanga.  Tons of cheese and they cover it with an amazing beef sauce.  Its a treat but you never know when they will have it.

bB-UrIXxmB4v7q3ElAp9MQ.review_text: I should... be kickin myself for not having gone to this place sooner.   It was a win from the moment I walked inside and I smelled the yummy food. A lovely full bar and everything at such low prices!? How did i not know about this place?! I will never know!!  I was in on X/Mas eve with some friends. We drink and ate. It was one stop shopping for such a lovely afternoon. I will be back there to get some more food and take full advantage of the kick butt bar on it prices.  Go there and try beer. They have so many beers that you can choose that are from around the world. With that said an adventure needs to be taken right on down there.

7eUYVb1BIJji1O6zmCPFLA.review_text: Food is great, ambiance is special, portions are plentiful. I love this place!!!! I got the lamb shanks which were absolutely amazing. The potatoes and carrots that come with her cooked perfectly! My other half has been here many many times and he brought me here for the first time. He's a big eater and he got the Bbq brisket which he LOVES!!!! I'm not a bbq sauce fan but I did take bite and I actually enjoyed it very much! They are open late so that's a Plus Plus Plus!!!

ef_cOqHQxl2a6R0zxxKIsg.review_text: After a night of partying, this is the place to be if you're craving a meal. It's great comfort food for the prices and the portions are amazing! I felt so stuffed afterwards.  I had the Corn Beef and Caggage, but I wanted my friend's boyfriend's brisket. It tasted better than what I ordered. Damn it.

ZOY3wZx-nDaVWJBP6h4ntQ.review_text: 3.5 stars.   This place is pretty decent. It was funny, I went here w/my people for lunch, and out of the blue- "hey I have been here before!" A long long time ago, when I was a youngin I ended up here on a trip to SF w/my cousin. I'm rambling, sorry, but I always remembered this place, but couldn't for the life of me remember the name. Anyhoo, I ordered a pastrami sandwich. It was pretty good- not the best in the world, but still good. To me, the pastrami tasted A LOT like corned beef. I also prefer the meat be sliced a bit thinner, but overall, it was pretty tasty. The portions here are pretty hefty too, especially for the price you pay (which is not a lot). The guys behind the counter were fairly nice and our drink waitress was as well. Kind of neat little place. Oh, and the pickles in the little barrel were great! :)

5-vUIV6C3JeSdJ4_5ze-0g.review_text: Mmm!  I have seen this place so many times but never gave it a try until New Years Eve.  With limited options available, I decided to check out who had better yelp reviews and it was Tommy's, so I gave it a go.  I ordered a turkey sandwich on light rye & a side of mashed potatoes...oh my God, so bomb and wayy too filling! I ate half of my potatoes and sandwich before throwing in the towel with a slight food coma.  The turkey was very moist and cooked better than my dads (sorry dad, love you!) & the mashed potatoes and gravy were bomb.  I love that this place serves real food!  Not the frozen boxed crap.   My friend order the clam chowder and pastrami sandwich.  She said it was the best clam chowder she's ever had (I'll take her word for it since I don't eat chowder) and that the pastrami sandwich and beans were bomb. Oh we also split a giant chocolate chip cookie, mmm  my sweet tooth loved it!  After sitting there trying to recover my friends wanted to go get a beer from the bar.  They have a wide variety of drinks and the bartender was very friendly and she was a cutie.   I definitely will be coming back :)

XJhmTEAJuYRgIP4b9wMcTw.review_text: Would you like some meat with your meat?  How about a tall glass of meat?  Some meatsticks on the side perhaps, with a little meat dipping sauce?  Oh, and have you tried our selection of meats?  They are quite meaty.

uW7XyPhz_Ifk4muvsZf20Q.review_text: Heading over there now, eaten here a few times and for the price/taste. It's totally awesome. I like the french dip

6ODieNljbP7Z-EZG45Tefg.review_text: dang it.  another joint that i got trapped into coming after I saw Guy Fieri's Diner's, Drive-ins and Drives on Food Network.  He is such a fatso.  All he does is eat....deep inside, I envy him...he just gets paid to eat fatty foods around the country and barely talk about em.    it's a hype.  buffalo stew and bbq briskets are plain.  It's cash only.  There was no wow factor like it promised on the show.  But some highlights do include low prices and their AMAAZING monday special oxtail pasta (easily 4.5 stars).  I can't wait to come and try their thursday lamb shank special!    once again, this world always offers false hopes and promises.  We fall for their tricks over and over again.  We are always looking around for something/someone to fully satisfy us.

xEzDkpwXTU6Nh2HnE_HFRw.review_text: Tommy's Joynt is old-school San Francisco. If you're looking for a modern, clean restaurant with plentiful vegan options and a long wine list, this is NOT that place. If you need some meat with a cheap beer at midnight, and you could care less about what the walls and tablecloth look like, this is the place for you. Yes, it's cash only, but there's an ATM inside with a $2 surcharge.  This was my first visit in several years. It was late, it'd been a really long day, and we needed some hearty grub. Since we were there after midnight, in the middle of the week, there was plenty of parking. It was definitely a local crowd. We had the turkey dinner. You get two sides with it; we didn't find anything else we liked, but the guy at the counter gently insisted we get something. The husband eventually had an extra side of potatoes, and I went with the cole slaw. We were pleasantly surprised with the turkey. It looked dry as it got carved, but it was actually pretty moist. Everything else was tasty, too. Our dinners and two sodas came to under $25. While I didn't have any booze, their bar is pretty epic... and cheap.  I really need to come here more often.

yQYOlzzlEIc9VwVPHlPtAg.review_text: I have to agree with jason g. I really really wanted to like Tommy's Joynt give that it's such a local favorite. But really? It was just underwhelming. I too ordered the meatball sandwich and got a piece of french bread drenched in sauce with two meatballs on top, and a sprinkling of parmesan. Now maybe I'm just finicky, but I can't stand a messy sandwich that a) you can't eat with your hands b) falls apart if you try to pick it up. So this was basically my worst nightmare - one that required a fork and knife.  The food wasn't bad as such, and you can't  beat the prices. I think I was just expecting something really exceptional and received something average. I'll try it again, maybe I'll up it a star or two next time.

gUImpcHjsI63rShqS4YItA.review_text: Just go here and eat. It's an experience you want to have. I ate here several times when I was last in San Fran and it was like an awakening. This is the place for meaty hearty meals. I only wish there was more than 5 stars available. I'd go on and on but suffice to say I wish I lived next door to this place because the food is worth getting fat for, and I would, so maybe it's best that it's far away from me.

trXQvZjYXK1eTFIqfHaw8A.review_text: I love this place mainly because it's one of the VERY FEW places that hasn't changed with the sugence of new era spots to eat, hang out, and drink, etc.  This place DEFINES what San Francisco had come to be.  You can enjoy a YUMMY plate of Beef Brisket, Burgundy Beef, or Roast Beef, Sausage Sandwich, Chili, while looking around at the old pics of SF, as well as some artifacts from SF as well.    Prices are definately reasonable, and the food is GOOD, not THE GREATEST, but definately GOOD and Enjoyable, which in combination with the ambience and history, earns my 5 star rating! =)

-aAILLByve7p3gRpmpzyMg.review_text: My family has been eating here for three generations.  It's fantastic...My favorite is the pastrami on sourdough, add some hot mustard (on the table), and pickles-we're in business.  The coleslaw, potato salad, and clam chowder are tasty additions too.  I can't really complain though...every sandwich I've had was delicious.  It's fun, funky, and completely original.  The building couldn't get more character.  It does get a little warm after the place fills up, but I usually head over for an early lunch to bypass the crowds.  Bring plenty of cash though; they don't accept credit cards.

SHS8VT0dqzqbOwFoCjJu8w.review_text: I don't get the hype. The meat was lukewarm and flavorless, the vegetables were watery and straight out of the can and I was physically pushed by the staff while I was trying to sit down. If there is supposed to a charm in such a rundown establishment, they ought to try and get SOMETHING right, but this place doesn't.

FUO62486I3-NaJN-E_tkmg.review_text: All I have to say is hot Pastrami sandwich. Its amazing! Its the best thing at Tommys Joynt. This Hof Brau is a San Francisco landmark. They have an amazing beer selection as well. Remember to bring cash because they do not take plastic.  Also this place is great because it is open late.. I think until two or three am. Def beats Taco bell for a drunk snack after hitting the bars downtown, Do not go here with a vegetarian- there are no real good meat free options here.

AXZW1NarhTRzEVl5a1vQSw.review_text: Tommy's Joynt's Beef Brisket Dinner with mashed potatoes?  YES PLEASE!  Came here only once, but once is all the time you need to fall for this place.  Their brisket is one of the juiciest slabs of meat that will grace your tongue for a mere $10.  It really melts and falls apart nicely in your mouth.  Super soft and succulent, and very easy to slice.  The gravy and sauce is like a watered down barbeque sauce, which may sound gross to some, but it actually works out perfectly with the meat.  Mashed potatoes are not to die for, but the gravy is, for it is the same watered down barbeque sauce.  If you're making a visit to the city, don't miss out on Tommy's Joynt.  Don't fall into those tourist traps on Fisherman's Wharf.  Go here.  It does look kind of like a dark soup kitchen when you go inside, but don't be a hater on its interior! It's all about the food.  I believe this was also on the food network, and for good reason too!

UrR6mPkYhzAwD6StcbuH2Q.review_text: We were passing   through the city to get to Tiburon on New Years day--We saw this gem on DDD--And said we would give it a shot--OMG--The inside is a psychedlic trip of old nosalgia--Old coke  and beer signs--And numerous freaky things on the wall--Way cool--  I had a roasted turkey sandwich and it was so fresh and divine--The au jus seemed weird with the bird so I skipped that--My man had the corn beef with swiss and it was divine--He got the mac and cheese and that was just plain gross--Skip that side--We loved TJ--

nN8kfrd56Nl-Cr-6jqh53w.review_text: I don't know if it's that i remember this place better than it was or if this place has worsened this much, but it was absolutely horrible! I don't get these favorable reviews? it's cheap, but cheap quality, and i wouldn't want it for free. I am an SF native that enjoyed this place when i was a kid, but came back and was so sorry that I did. One of the worst meals that I have ever had. Mom and I ordered the turkey leg, which was bland, and the skin was soggy, not crispy. The so called "italian" dressing was all vinegar no oi. Never ever again!

Jpq1pHiNSYg0zC1XW4Pcvg.review_text: If you're craving a lot of meat, this is the place to go.  I think my favorite is the pastrami plate, although it's best when you go with friends and each order something different to share.

VpREWOjt5Pna6OIgXI9Jcg.review_text: I don't know why I hadn't come here sooner. It's hard to say what I expected it to look like, but I was definitely surprised. It's large and you can tell the stuff on the walls has been there for years, maybe decades.  It has an expansive menu of heart-stopping favorites, and it's all cheap. Note the single dollar sign when you're out and about! I ordered a beef brisket sandwich at the bar, which was pretty good. Mac and cheese also pretty good. Pint o' beer, standard. So the food wasn't stellar, but the fact that you can eat, drink, and hang in comfortable surroundings for cheap (in the middle of SF), boosts it from an easy 3 to a tentative, hopeful 4.   This was our starting spot before heading out to a movie, but I'd definitely make it a regular meet-up/destination spot for a casual get-together.

v8H8wBUVX8n40oo8rRdqqQ.review_text: Good home cooking and cheap.  My driver took me here for a quick bite before a business meeting.  I don't watch Guy whateverhisnameis, so I'd never heard of the place.  It's old school, no frills, stick-to-your-ribs goodness.  I'd rate higher, but good isn't great, and some of the interior could stand for an update (e.g., carpet).

TVPTbgstJQ-BXDo3eQIZQw.review_text: Garb! Went there for lunch, what a waste. DONT BELIEVE THE HYPE! Jack in the box, MCDONALD'S, In & out, Popeyes Chicken, may be better choices. Maybe dinner is better, I'll never know will not return.

VFxrLIlgApHIdOCrkAYIGA.review_text: This place is amazing. We ran in here on a monday night to get something to eat before a movie and were afraid it would take too long. Turns out it's a self-serve kinda place. You walk up to the meat counter area and order. The portions are HUGE and simple. You can get sides with your sandwich, I just went straight for corned beef on a roll with mayo and mustard. It barely fit in my mouth, it was that big!  Their beer selection is very good also. They even have Baltika, and more than just one number. Now that's something even Russian places don't usually have!  The decor was cute. The place is definitely a dive, don't take your girlfriend here on a romantic dinner, but it's good food at low prices and it's fast!

ArEOjGosnXWsFMvV6evHjw.review_text: Tommy's is a SF/Van Ness staple. A definite recommendation if you want true down-home comfort food.  It's the Harry's Hofbrau of San Francisco...one of those places where it's always thanksgiving (only not thanksgiving)!  Great for late night too!!

UKnxXIGoySM0KliHCcTn1A.review_text: This place has quickly become my favorite restaurant in SF. Cheap dinner (under $10 for a huge plate of meat, potatoes and your choice of salad) plus $4 Jameson equals me super ecstatic.  Always good for people watching - the other night, my best friend and I saw a guy cussing at the empty seat across from him whilst otherwise peacefully drinking his wine. The booths are labelled reserved for two or more people but he was sitting in one by himself. I remarked "Well, at least he thinks he's in a party of two".  Pastrami is fantastic and the lasagna is awesome. The brisket is not to my liking but that may be because as I age, I'm becoming more drawn to less cooked meats. Desserts are good too, though I rarely have room for them.  Seriously, where else can you find whiskey priced cheaper than Fat Tire? Being a whiskey girl, that just makes me happy.

IxKjgqLAG6teY_pqGnh9ZQ.review_text: MEAT.  I want  M - E - A - T... lots of it :-)!  After seeing, "30 Days of Night" (vampires in Alaska, very bloody -- lots of blood and fresh meat), Max and I decided to have dinner at Tommy's Joynt.  It was ironic that I was craving red meat after the movie considering how "gross" some of the scenes were.    What's the deal?  At my first visit, I wasn't really sure of what to do.  Then I figured out that you line-up like "cafeteria style" and order your dinner with all the sides you want.  Grab utensils and water.  Then, find an empty table.  Seconds later, order cocktails/drinks from the waitress.  EASY as 1-2-3.  There was a line outside the restaurant, but it moved really quickly.  BBQ Beef with rice, roll and potato salad for me; and Burgundy beef with rice and roll for Max.  The beef was so tender and not too fatty.  It was tasty and fulfilled my cravings.  I could do with less BBQ sauce and more rice though.    I would totally go back. Definitely.  How can I not, even for just a beer or two at the bar while watching a game on t.v.

REGjppkq2IkDLRQVmRj_Bg.review_text: I don't even know where to begin.  How about the fact that this place has 1,500 reviews and remains 4 stars!?!?  Seriously?!?  I mean I could eat off the floor and it would taste better than this "Joynt".  With "San Francisco Landmark" painted on the outside of this colorful building you know you're in for something good.  Once you've stepped inside your senses are a little overwhelmed.  Imagine a mix of Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Smuggler's Cove.  It feels like an old ship that has clearly sailed downward and sunk.  After waiting in the snakelike line the menu's are hard to figure out.  Every item has it's own board practically so instead of reading one sign where you'll pick your food you have to read about 50+ all with prices that appear as if they haven't changed since the place first opened.  The food area reminded me of a Chinese walkway with red-lights hovering above old meat that has clearly been crusted over and sitting there for a few days.  It was 6pm - you would think the food would be piping hot right?  Wrong. After my buddy ordered 4 plates of food I figured we'd have enough of a good taste test to see how this meal would pan out.  I inquired about the German sausage and was shown a silver tin of about 5 sausages floating to the top of some sort of thick liquid.... I chose to pass.  I'm not a fan of Thanksgiving day meals and this place seems to sell them all.  The open-faced meatball sandwich sounded like a safe choice or so I thought.  We sat down with 5 plates at our table.  My meatball sandwich which consisted of 4 oddly-shaped pieces of bread and sauce smothering TWO quarter sized meatballs.  you read that right, TWO.  I guess they were trying to save a buck by charging me $6 for this "meal" and skipping the meat.  I said "what the hell" and took a bite.  FIRST bite was a nice solid chunk of gristle which made for an unpleasant experience.  Needless to say I charged on and finished my meatballs - both of them.  That's it.  I had one small bite of bread and was dissatisfied as it appeared soggy and looked like it was left over from a day or two before.  My friend chose the pasta which tasted slimy and cold.  He ordered the turkey with stuffing, gravy and mashed potatoes.  The turkey was cold and gravy lukewarm.  Stuffing was horrible as he took one bite and spit it out.  The saving grace was the store-bought mashed potatoes that you obviously knew came from a box.  His side salad didn't look appealing at all, as if it came from the Round Table salad bar complete with "wooden" woven bowl.  The bread roll was probably the only thing on the menu that was edible as everything else was cold and sickeningly inedible.   I would never in a million years recommend Tommy's Joynt or say that it is anything close to a San Francisco Landmark.  Unless we're associating SF with horrible food.  Fear for your stomachs people.

lLfrDM_tbUgtXY63Z4HpUQ.review_text: Pulled Pork Tuesdays YUM!!!!!! 10/10 would go again.

aREzu8wiB_1NYMzi_TgN0A.review_text: MEAT, MEAT, MEAT! Came in here for lunch and had the dinner plate. The plate offers 2 sides, meat: round of beef, brisket...can't remember all the choices. Sides were salads, and mash potatoes, or veggies. What can be wrong with that? We had the potato salad, regular salad, bread with butter, and round of beef. All for $20.07?  That's absurd! Pay for your food after you get your food. Drinks? Find a table and have a seat, the waitress comes and takes your drink orders. $3.50 for 2 sodas. Yeah, you pay for drinks at your table. Condiments such as hot mustard, mild mustard, and horseradish is at your table...just what I needed; some horseradish on my meat. Chow down and enjoy yourself in a "bbq" meat joint with friends...like everyone else does.

U3sCAJc4_E3MGC1jGi19gQ.review_text: Visit #1 (11/27/13): My pre-Thanksgiving lunch. Ordered the pulled pork sandwich along with a turkey leg and a side of cole slaw. Yes, my eyes are bigger than my stomach... sadly, not by much! Overall great meal! Stuffed and happy. Bill: about $20 (with tips)  Visit #2 (2/12/14): Ordered the buffalo stew over rice. DON'T GET IT! The meat was very dry. The portion was very little for a $10.xx dish.   It's sad that bad experiences outweigh good ones. Hence the 2-star rating. Sorry!

oyJhBgQh9q_1TG0Z3EqG1Q.review_text: I've been here twice and both times was a-ok.. I absolutely love the Clam chowder tho!! Best in SF!! *Steak sandwich was really tough, tasted like you put a thick slice of meat on a sandwich roll. *Pastrami sandwich was good but not enough meat like they advertise"mile high." There was the pastrami meat stuffed in a sandwich roll with a side of au juice. No lettuce or anything. Also, lots of chunks of fat in the meat. So much that I was chewing and spitting out the fat at the same time.. haha.. gross, but the meat was tender.Lol *Corned beef dinner was really salty!! Mashed potatoes tasted like boxed and beans were a bit on the sweet side.  *Potato salad was horrible! I think I had better at Safeways. *Garlic Bratwurt was very bland. Tasted more like a bologna dog.   I have high hopes for this place but definitely will come back just for the clam chowder.   It was kind of strange that you order in a line like a deli store and seat yourself where ever but then they have a server to take your drink orders? I just thought it should at least be the other way around.. Lol..

9N-jabBo0hrrF8aVLIwnMw.review_text: Damn, this place is good!  The smell of corned beef was in the air as I waited at the bus stop across the street.  Needless to say, I was back not long after to experience this San Francisco legend.  If you haven't yet experienced SF's greatest hofbrau, you need to go ASAP.

li85I9BtJme3KAmN02CzEQ.review_text: this place is a time honored place since the 20's.  It's beer list is almost as good as their food menu.  It is a great place for out-of-town visitors and friends with little taste in drunken venue.  Yummy, filling and oh so bad for you =)~

pdVcVtgBeYiauqwC-lxthA.review_text: Had the turkey plate. Was alright, nothing said "WOW". Tons of beers.had a good time w/ friends. Staff was cool. Typical Hoff Brau IMO.

eDvP9E32tZisqzZM7PjvPw.review_text: After seeing Tommy's Joynt on Diners, Drive-In's, and Dives I was looking forward to eating here.  While I have driven by this place many times, I never knew what to expect .  Their food is standard hofbrau fair (turkey legs, beef, pastrami, etc) but their prices are great and the portions are generous.  You order from a counter cafeteria style, pay, and then seat yourself.  I'd definitely eat here again if I was in the area.

WJIEdPeGjP35RScfyRr01w.review_text: Ted Nuget would be so proud. Beer, Meat and Mashed Potatoes are you in line yet? This is a straight up Hungry Man meal to go for real. With a line out the door and an ATM inside (cash only) you know you've found a happening place to eat some grub.  After eating small eats at another place, my group was serious about eating up and getting full so I took them to Tommy's.  I don't know if it's part ye old curiousity or just has character, either way while you're waiting in the line there's so much on the walls and ceiling to look at you will not get bored as you walk through the assembly line.   They ordered a french dip sammy to split, I stuck with clam chowder (still full from the last place) and called it good. We paid and looked for a place to sit down. At 9pm it was pretty packed so we walked around to find a seat and found a dripping ceiling which made me think of a sinking wooden ship. Nothing too bad but thankfully we found a seat away from the dripping pipe, and munched on the food. The chowder was just right with the help of a trusty friend called Tapatio. The crowd is pretty mixed, like a typical game night hangout with a bunch of regulars.    This is no sinking ship and if I'm ever in need of good ol' fashioned comfort food this is the place to find me.

8be8GdTFsPdd_7YRczbk-g.review_text: Got the Buffalo Stew...but I wish I had gotten my friend's Brisket instead.   Seeing that it was my first time, I welcomed waiting in line so that I could actually decide what to get. Haha. The line moved pretty quickly. Not only is it served cafeteria style, but I would say the quality is close to that as well. Honestly, I wasn't super impressed, but then again, I didn't try the brisket and the lamb was only available on Thursdays? :(( meh.   Also, luckily I had cash, cause they're cash only. DUUUDE, we're in a time with Apple Pay, get with the times! It's a bit annoying to carry cash. :P  Maybe I didn't get the right item, but I was not wowed by my selection. Until next time, Tommy's Joynt.

UpKWv9Svnfar5QTuSVcN0w.review_text: I haven't been to a good haufbrau in many years. My grandparents used to take us for Saturday night dinner at one and Tommy's brought me right back to my childhood the minute I walked in the door.  Went today and had an open faced rare roast beef with so many delicious starches to compliment it that I was a happy happy woman all afternoon! Very energetic dining experience and a fun bar-room feel.   I'll be coming back here. Question - why are all hofbraus so dark?

0m-ehDDX-U_TiFstAQqfMg.review_text: Pretty average food. Cafeteria style dining: go in, get in line, order your food, pay, and find your own seat. I came with my family and it was pretty busy. We even had to bus our own table. We honestly didn't mind because we can understand how busy this particular restaurant can get, but it's not exactly welcoming to clean the table before you during your first visit. Whatever.  Food was pretty average; I've had better and I've had worse. Turkey was tender, but a bit dry. Mom had the roast beef that didn't have much flavor, but she loves A-1 sauce so what does she know. Also, there's a huge barrel of pickles that we took advantage of, so that was fun!   It's a place that you have to try at least once when visiting San Francisco because of its' history, and it's cash only.

9-Z0dL17BsmHmImqR4MFVA.review_text: Walking into tommy's, i love the first wiff of this place.  All the meat is tender, taste great and right in front of you.  You can see them slice every delectable piece.   I have a bad habit of getting the same thing repeatedly when i like a place, but there are a few things i'll eat here: the barbaque beef is bomb, the prime rib is awesome and their french dip is ridiculously good. mmmm....French Dip.    Warning...Be prepared because meals here aren't light.  After a some meat and a beer you'll want curl up and pass out.  Scrumptious!

snQ3REUAJqmm6ha5AJnKTA.review_text: OK, I had the  a great time here with some friends from NYC. We  all had something different  and it was all good. I kinda loved the BBQ beef so juicy and delicious and the mushroom salad finished off with the carrot cake and the apple pie. we all left smiling and for some odd reason singing Barry Manilow, but the place is awesome.

2MbKqqyCbh5VlwbsIYq5Cw.review_text: Not entirely impressed with the food but found the decor interesting and the experience worthwhile. Ordered the steak sandwich which ended up being comprised of ground meat with a healthy helping of mushroom sauce and a side of mashed potatoes. It was good, but certainly not great. I also got a bloody mary which I was hoping would be legit here but ended up being just tomato juice and vodka.  Definitely would recommend a one-time stop in just to give it a try. As for me, I came, I ate, I drank, I'm done.

0iVOecu2vHeyW0v5pctyhA.review_text: Every great city needs a cafeteria style, pastrami and brisket serving, gravy laden, free pickle providing restaurant for salty cured meat and cheap beer.  Tommy's provided me a fix for juicy meat, silky mashed potatoes and stiff drinks.  Its delicious, cheap and sets the tone for a long night of drinking in SF.

USZ6XUarw563pg1ON8TaVA.review_text: This place has a lot of character from the inside and out. Their food is great and well priced! Plenty of places to sit, their eating area is two floors. I'm a fan of their brisket or corned beef sandwiches which is around 6 bucks or so. Plus they have a bar. Highly recommend you to check it out!  Quick tip: Don't know what to order? They'll let you sample some of their  selections to help you out.

Ma_gwnVShENgTuhHNpAvyQ.review_text: Anything on the menu is an excellent option.  Good value doesn't even begin to describe this place.  Huge portions for cheap.  A bit heavy handed on the seasonings, but who wouldn't enjoy a hearty meal of mashed potatoes and stewed brisket?  The crowd and ambiance is fun, and there is ample seating upstairs because it does tend to get crowded and attracts a line.  PROTIP:  CASH ONLY.

_q2YQ2FvcF7Cr2PmKpJPMQ.review_text: Lamb shank. I do got to say that it was good , I took my family to the city for the week for vacation we ate just about ever-were yet ,"Tommy's Joynt " fill us up for only 30 buck good food and better price

JqIyaS9QAh9k5FO02nIqEQ.review_text: I'm a gal that loves a big ol' slab of meat. And counter here offers lots of them!  I'm currently stuck on the roast beef sandwich. Carved to order, perfectly cooked, and just so damn delicious. I get mine with mustard, and honestly, it doesn't even need that.   The cooks are friendly, they have a great selection of beer, and it's on the cheap.   Eat this food. Be happy.

MizlaDrXhL99TrWWXXkO5Q.review_text:
What? Did someone say "joint?" Oh, Tommy's Joynt, right.
  For me Tommy's Joynt is like Carol Channing doing "Hello Dolly." They roll her out and she's all old and wrinkled. Her tits are sagging and the voice is kind of blown out but you sit there and politely laugh and cheer but in your heart you're thinking, "Man, this shit is kind of sad."
  Despite the new paint job on the outside (there's a hand waving hello and below it it says "Hello Stranger!" God, I love that) the inside is somewhat dark and seems to be unchanged in the last 50 years. The menu reflects that as well but then again have you ever gone to a hof brau and been impressed by their innovative and playful menu? Thought not. They've got all the standbys, roast beef, corned beef, BBQ brisket (although I think they use corn starch or something to thicken their BBQ sauce. Say WHAT?!) and their "World Famous turkey breast." I doubt if people in COLMA are talking about this turkey breast but who am I to talk, I claim to have "World Famous dance moves." What, you haven't heard of that either?
  There's a full bar with an impressive selection of beer and for some reason you have to order and pay for all beverages separately.
  Don't get me wrong, I like Tommy's Joynt but it's kind of like a dive bar in the sense that you can find comfort in being a total slob and knowing no one is going to judge you. This place is like Carol Channing herself. They're both San Francisco institutions and they've both been around for like a hundred and fifty years.

pfHICN67xeftkMIJyrvsIQ.review_text: After a concert, we were on our way home until we passed by this place and remembered it being featured on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. We busted a square and found parking...  Upon arrival it was pretty packed with patrons for a Friday evening around 10pm.   We ordered: - Corned beef sandwich on a dinner roll [not good] - BBQ Brisket over rice [okay] - 2 baked beans [good] - 1 mac and cheese [okay]  Some noteworthy items to mention:  I was not impressed with my corned beef sandwich. It was just two-three slices of corned beef in a dinner roll with nothing else to jazz it up. Even the side of au jus did not help the sandwich... I've had great french dip sandwiches that were amazing alone and even more spectacular with au jus before and that was at Sonoma Chicken Coop. Though this is a completely different sandwich, its flavors consisted of nothing distinct enough to make my taste buds even twitch.  I'm sure I'm missing something here, hopefully when I do return in the future I'll order something more praiseworthy.

IdPCYdvRqoeqz3h_QuN3ug.review_text: I'm actually surprised that I hadn't heard of this place yet. I was in SF for a photography workshop and decided to stop in for my 2 hour break.   The line bunched up at the door, the servers were difficult to understand, there wasn't any seating, but wow, it was sure worth it!   I had a BBQ beef sandwich and a side of mac 'n cheese. The sandwich was delicious. The BBQ sauce was nice and tangy and came in a little syrup pitcher to drizzle with. The meat was very well cooked and tender. The mac ' cheese was overly peppery and didn't have a whole lot of flavor, but they had tons of other salads to choose from. I wish I'd made another choice on my side. But there will be another chance...shortly I'm sure.

FoPy5PSHEqALnXGPoYFWuw.review_text: Lived here for 12 years, and only now have visited Tommy's.  Great NY deli style food, and great prices.

lXJpiJHkIiLv4ntFmVhDvw.review_text: I can see it now. my last day of work. if God is kind, He will not let me retire from my pighole company; instead, He will reward my toil and trouble by dropping several billion bucks in my lap. and on that day, I will show up for work at 7 am. I will work my accounts. for lunch, I will go to Tommy's Joynt, dump down 3 or 4 Absolut & sodas, then order a FAT corned beef on rye to go. I will stumble my way back to my office, march straight to the big boss, and tell that hag to eat my panties, her managerial skills are grossly incompetent, we are fortunate we haven't yet declared bankruptcy.  I will then go home forever and gobble up my lovely sandwich.

aHbxZxh8Vb8y_KzBaz4vUQ.review_text: we sadly were not able to eat here when we were up north but so many great beer choices.  We want to make another bay area trip just to eat here.

RCKdmKDZRd-RovZVtNSCLA.review_text: Sure, I love pastrami, but that's not what I've been here for so far! Let's put it this way: the AMC Van Ness is right across the street, and one can either gulp popcorn and an icee while waiting for a film to start, or one can choose to come over here for 45 minutes when purchasing tickets early enough. I'd prefer such items from Tommy's as their Aroma Coma or Weihenstephaner any day!  Do wish to try their pastrami some day... Mmm, looks tasty, and they're well-known for it! Another day, another review...

gcaevnksCwEWwHTMtD4DsA.review_text: Wholesome, cheap, right next to the Regency, great pulled pork. What more could you want?

-aUOAVRvdLnryQLI4tY8LQ.review_text: I came here with a friend for lunch and it was a decent experience, with a few caveats. She lamb shank was GREAT! I will order it again and it's probably the reason why I will come again. My friend ordered brisket and it was good, but a little fatty. The portions however were fantastic!  Nonetheless, the side dishes were just meh and I did not like their cucumber salad. If tasted rubbery. Service was also funky, as the guys behind the counter were friendly, but the cashier was a bit, it wouldn't say rude, but she seemed she was bothered to ring us up. Strange since we are bringing business and all. Otherwise, for a place that serves ginormous portions at decent prices, this was pretty good.

pBUhruF3QDDB8gOpon_lNw.review_text: Gotta Love This Place......  It looks like a Bohemia Grandmother decorated this place...god  love it.  I have been here a few times and I have only tried the corned beef sandwich, and I love it...fresh, soft, tender corned beef, served with an Au Jus...and a spicy mustard= a bit of heaven on the streets of San Francisco...I want to try something new there, but I get so much pleasure from the corned beef sammy, I'm literally afraid to!  Dare I say this place rivals IKE's (another one of my favorites)....The pricing is right and you have a selection of different HOT meats cut to order...try that German Potato salad as well...a nice compliment to any sammy.  This place is a big "win" in my opinion.

lxd_0addywk4y4Q9rfB5Yg.review_text: Went there for the first time for my friend's birthday. I ordered the corn beef sandwich, and I have to say it was pretty good along with a carrot cake which was really too sweet for my taste. It seems like it would be a little crowded during peak times, but we were there around 1pm and was able to get sit down right away. I would probably go back there again the only bad thing is that they don't accept credit cards for the food half but I didn't order any drinks from the bar so that part I don't know if they accept credit cards.
